No being is above suspicion, no motive shall remain hidden. No peace without war.
When no fixture presents itself, one must simply make their own.
The Lady of Mists is a patron of the hidden and the lost. Her presence is felt most strongly within the mists of Yvresse, where she is said to guide wanderers to safety.
The Elves of Tor Yvresse contain a deep hatred, war has scarred their hearts and steeled their souls. Tor Yvresse will not fall again.
An extremely light yet resilient material, Ithilmar gives the same protection as heavy steel, but without slowing down its wearer.
Together with Stormwing, Eltharion cuts through Ulthuan’s foes like a wind of blades as the mighty Griffon rakes and claws with savagery.
This rune-encrusted longsword has been passed down through Eltharion’s family for generations, bestowing unto him the zeal of his forefathers.
The ceremonial crown of he who protects Yvresse’s ancient metropolis is an inspirational symbol of dogged determination.
Unmake what is theirs to safeguard what is ours.
Steel that bites deeper than the flesh.
No dark corner of the world will serve to hide you from the Mistwalkers.
These walls have stood since ages past, and they will not fall until this world crumbles into nothing!
Dragon Princes are the only Elves who would never dip their banners for the Phoenix King, holding to an honour said to have been granted by Caledor himself!
When it is done there shall remain but mounds of ash as far as the eye can see.
Caledorians are renowned for their arrogance. It is however hard to argue their proficiency as elite cavalry.
It is not the Dragon you should fear…
Imrik is prince of the silent realm of Caledor. Despite the decline of the Dragons, Imrik does not waver in his duty.
The age of Dragons is long past, but the pride of Caledorians doth never wane. The fires that once raged upon the peaks now rages within every Caledorian Elf.
The Dragon Prince’s unwavering steed is bedecked in plates and scales of ‘sky-silver’ that mimic the appearance of a mighty Drake.
Imrik’s fanatically loyal Drake is a symbol of the Elf Lord’s irrefutable eminence as the last true Dragon Prince.
Donned by the masters of the House of Caledor, this ensorcelled armour has endured over four thousand years of battles.
Caledor is home to Vaul's Anvil, the site of a great temple to the God of Smiths. The work of the priests of Vaul binds the Winds into steel, and forges peerless magical arms and armour.

The wild Griffons of Ulthuan are creatures of noble bearing and keen intelligence, with whom Elves form bonds that only death can shatter.
The wild Griffons of Ulthuan are creatures of noble bearing and keen intelligence, with whom Elves form bonds that only death can shatter.
Fighting upon an Arcane Phoenix, Teclis rides the magical tempests, harnessing the power of the howling Winds sweeping through the world of mortals.
Maintaining a chariot that can support Grom's immense weight pushes Goblin engineering skills to their limits.
Cool, calm, and collected. Yeah, right!
This one doesn't even relax in their own company, so reserved is their nature.
Fortitude? Strength of character? Do me a favour – this yellow-bellied poltroon has none.
Definitely not the life and soul of the party; they exude melancholy and depression.
Tempers, like wicks, can be ignited. Watch the anger burn.
Action, inaction, change – you name it, this one will work against the prevailing wind.
You don't want to be on the wrong side of this one's ire – it's explosive to say the least!
Not every cloud has a silver lining.
Whatever quality is needed to stand guard over the Asur way of life, this one has it in abundance.
If ever there was a candidate for a relaxing break at an all-inclusive spa, it was this one.
Looking "not too well" has become a permanent condition. Clearly, they're lacking essential herbs.
They say two are better than one. They are, of course, totally wrong in every respect.
Chance is like magic – it can be harnessed to the individual's will.
Every fibre of their being is charged and ready for action – wherever, whenever.
Impressively energetic for a thousand years old – even by their own reckoning.
Through their veins a charge is racing. Energy, filling the ominous void within.
Staying this supple takes effort. You don’t get definition like that by sitting about and drinking.
If you need anything, there are guards outside the doors. Many guards.
There's usually a right way and a wrong way to do anything. This one generally gets it wrong.
Machinery – and indeed progress of any kind – is anathema to this one, because there's no substitute for good, honest toil.
This one can never leave something alone. They always have to meddle.
Much of the Ulthuan skyline built over the last thousand years is down to this one’s sterling endeavours.
Too late, too late! will be the cry, when the one with the bargains passes you by.
Fortunately, there are some who really apply themselves to the problems of the world. Just as well, otherwise we'd be… Oh wait...
If it requires accuracy and organisation, this one is your Elf. Not so much fun at parties, however.
There's always a way – always an angle. You just have to find it.
An individual of exceptional skill and worth; the very embodiment of sagacity.
Pointy-'ead is legendary among the Greenskins, who both fear and respect his martial prowess.
Imrik is the last of the line of Caledor the Dragontamer, and shares his lineage's martial excellence and affinity for Dragonkind.
Kadon, a master of forms, was able to shift his shape into anything he chose. This mastery is used to summon a Great Eagle, as if Kadon himself fights for you.
Kadon, a master of forms, was able to shift his shape into anything he chose. This mastery is used to summon a Great Eagle, as if Kadon himself fights for you.
Skarsnik has a unique history with working in the dark, and his expertise in the matters of ambush and betrayal are legendary!
Take it, take it all! Every las' bit of it!
It ain't really hidin, jus tac-tik-kel moving is all!
When push comes to shove, make sure you aren't the one being pushed!
While locating enough paint for the job ain't easy, no one can deny the results!
Wurrzag's feet move to a rhythm only he can hear, but he's more than happy to share!
Fighting Wurrzag is relatively disconcerting. His feet stamp out the wild of rhythm of the Savage Orcs as he jigs in and out of the fight.
This entry is used to group together skills for Drycha's Quest Battle
Throt’s successes as the most twisted and ingenious Master Mutator of Clan Moulder means he is now one of the infamous nine Lords of Hell Pit.
Long ago, Drycha held court on the tainted ground where Morghur’s blood was spilt amongst the roots of the once-glorious Tree of Woe.
Some say Naestra and Arahan are the lightest and darkest aspects of Ariel’s spirit made manifest, her mercy and passion split from her soul.
Scurrying over their host with feverish abandon, Netlings snag the weapons of enemies that come too close with webs of magical filaments.
Scurrying over their host with feverish abandon, Netlings snag the weapons of enemies that come too close with webs of magical filaments.
The staring eyes and tattered wings of tiny, glowing Elves befuddle enemy minds, sending them into a sleep-like trance.
Mirthfully looming out from their host, Terrors take on their most fearsome aspect to dampen the spirits of their horrified prey.
Mirthfully looming out from their host, Terrors take on their most fearsome aspect to dampen the spirits of their horrified prey.
Radiants are sponges for magical energy, manifesting as little more than blurred shapes of pure light that beckon the Winds to their host.
The Despairs are among the most feared Spites within Athel Loren, their arrival always foretelling imminent death.
Hiding in their hosts' hollows are fiendish forms, ready to strike out at any who draw near.
Unleashed upon a foe, these aggressive manifestations of the forest are utilised for their needle-like arrows that inflict painful wounds from afar.
Unleashed upon a foe, these aggressive manifestations of the forest are utilised for their needle-like arrows that inflict painful wounds from afar.
Shrikes take on various frightening forms, moving like quicksilver to target the eyes, and even enter foes’ bodies to attack their very minds.
Bounding from branch to bow, the Luminescents’ magical spoors alight upon allies’ weapons to bestow a minor but lethal enchantment.
For the gaudier Warlord, Clan Moulder offers their most bloated Pox Rats as mounts to flail, crush, and savage a way through the enemy’s ranks.
Forest Dragons are not known for their recklessness, but the venturesome Ceithin-Har is a true reflection of the Sisters’ combative aspect.
A specially-engineered breed of Rat Ogre, the Bonebreaker has a braced platform strapped or bolted to its back for carrying a Skaven Warlord to battle.
The ascension up the greasy pole of the Skaven military hierarchy starts in the brood.
A lifetime spent witnessing the ramifications of others falling short of a Warlord’s expectations makes the fear of failure all-consuming.
Yes-yes, it is deadly to attack mighty Warlord! Great Horned One watches over him-him!
For the gaudier Warlord, Clan Moulder offers their most bloated Pox Rats as mounts to flail, crush, and savage a way through the enemy’s ranks.
Even the most vicious and impetuous monstrosities can be 'encouraged' to do one’s bidding with a quick jolt of Warpstone-generated electricity.
As soon as the Packmaster unleashes his beloved 'pets' upon the battlefield, their bloodthirsty hunt begins!
Summoned forth from filth-ridden sewers, disease-carrying amalgamations of rat and wolf cause pestilent havoc in the enemy’s ranks.
A things-catcher and whip are not all that makes a Packmaster, for only the best have monster-goading down to a fine art.
Moulder’s most elite Packmasters are known as Master Moulders, fearless wranglers who excel at instilling greater control and discipline into their packs.
Show a Packmaster a hero and he will show you a tragedy.
Catching lesser foes is hardly a challenge, but is undeniably useful to provide extra rations for the pack.
Good at keeping all sorts of nasty creatures in check.
Even the hunchbacked and mutated things of Hell Pit’s warrens can be frenzied forward by the stinging pain of Throt’s scathing minotaur-hide whip.
For the gaudier Warlord, Clan Moulder offers their most bloated Pox Rats as mounts to flail, crush, and savage a way through the enemy’s ranks.
A birch’s oils can soften its wood, but once dry can harden branches into lethal clubs of war.
Not even the fiercest weather conditions can strike down a hardy and long-lived oak, for it endures all seasons.
The willow is a harbinger of spring, and a conduit of lifeforces that can bolster a tree to withstand the direst of circumstances.
Wherever winter retreats, the birch is amongst the first to sprout forth, for its vibrance is its greatest strength.
Those who adopt the oak’s warlike aspect typically stand on the front line, such is the sheer structural strength of its genus.
Once the willow’s warlike aspect is adopted, branches and leaves droop and overlap, absorbing anything that may cause harm.
The promise of spilt blood rouses the forest’s predators from their lairs, salivating in anticipation of the slaughter.
The wild beasts of the forest always sense the emotions of the Treemen, empathising with their pain over eons of loss.
Whether roused for war or retreated into the dreaming lands of sleep, the Treemen’s innate magic nurtures the forest and its lesser spirits.
Though the wargrove’s Elves remain under the enchanted delusion that they fight for their queen, the spell’s debilitations have been overcome.
Any compassion remaining in Durthu’s ancient mind has eroded, making him little more than a destroyer.
No mere fire of the natural world can burn that which is born of Athel Loren.
The sheer weight of Durthu's hatred is great enough to seep into the very land upon which he treads.
Durthu's connection with the forest is absolute, his mere presence enough to harness the power of the other, long-slumbering Ancients.
Durthu's towering form is as unyielding and implacable as the earth itself.
Orion is never left wanting when he reaches for his quiver.
All Asrai heed Orion’s horn – even before it is sounded, it exists as a portent that the Wild Hunt is imminent.
Those unfortunate enough to find themselves in the hunter’s sights will not escape their attentions, for it is already too late.
The rites of the summer gave you your purpose. Our songs filled you with the blood of Kurnous. He lives, through you. He hunts, through you...
Foliage and shrubbery oft suffice to hide from the mundane, but the King in the Woods is anything but.
This ritualistic war dance requires neither rhythm nor order, enabling evasion of the enemy’s clumsy attacks, and lethal counterattacks.
The Lord charges their troops to fight for Athel Loren, for their very souls are tethered to its fate.
Using rhythmic incantations endowed and employed by Loec himself to avoid Slaanesh’s gaze, one can stay unseen and uncaught.
Once consumed by Loec’s aspect, one can instinctively evade attack through trickery, mimicking his deception of the Dark Gods.
Once consumed by Loec’s aspect, one can instinctively evade attack through trickery, mimicking his deception of the Dark Gods.
Waystalkers’ keen eyes can spot an enemy at a distance that defies belief, and so they demand the same of their troops.
Coeddil's curdled heart attracts the most malignant and terrifying spirits.
By the eternal will of the Ancients, the forest looks after its own.
Coeddil has weaved the Winds of Magic since the world was in its infancy.
Even if it takes millennia, every crime committed against the forest shall be accounted for!
Lurking amongst Coeddil’s branches and hollows are swarms of chittering Spites, all drawn to his pungent malice.
Deep within the blackest forests, Coeddil's followers have awaited his return, their seething rage intensified by every passing year.
Hate can drive one to make... unusual alliances.
Once, Coeddil brought life wherever he walked. Now what growth he inspires is sour and rotten.
With its magnificent frame and the great plumes of steam of its snorting breath, the Great Stag instils unflinching valour into those who ride it.
With its magnificent frame and the great plumes of steam of its snorting breath, the Great Stag instils unflinching valour into those who ride it.
When one knows ways to inflict incapacitating injury, even upon that which is hard to kill, everything is prey.
Enhanced by magic, the laws of nature grant the wargrove a heightened ability to heal its ranks from light energy alone.
Tree Spirits have no greater camouflage than to become as still as an insentient forest.
The forest has myriad ways to cause discomfort, pain and death to those foolhardy enough to make unwanted contact with its denizens.
The bond between rider and steed goes beyond friendship or family; they act as one.
Its forehead adorned with a spiral horn, this noble mount carries the Spellsinger where their magical gifts are needed most.
Fly on your wings, like an eagle. Touch the sun. Track the foe, ambush, and defeat.
The bond between rider and steed goes beyond friendship or family; they act as one.
Its forehead adorned with a spiral horn, this noble mount carries the Spellsinger where their magical gifts are needed most.
Fly on your wings, like an eagle. Touch the sun. Track the foe, ambush, and defeat.

Fly on your wings, like an eagle. Touch the sun. Track the foe, ambush, and defeat.
Isha's protection can protect the faithful Asrai through the darkest of days.
All Elves are intrinsically magical beings, but Asrai Spellweavers practice spellcraft free of Ulthuan’s stiff-necked morality and Naggaroth’s heedless sadism.
Skilled spellweavers can turn the forest upon their enemies with frightening ease, summoning grasping, twisted roots and branches to smother their foes.
Some return from the wilds silent and brooding, others with thrilling tales that inspire and teach.
A grim wanderer, touched by the wild, this character eschews the company of other Asrai to hone their skills.
You can take the Northman out of Chaos, but you can’t take Chaos out of the Northman.
A Berserker has a tad more cognitive ability than a Rat Ogre – the mind of the former at least allows one to be a semi-competent quartermaster!
As it turns out, leading a Norscan clan and commanding a pack of monsters are not that different from one another.
The Unclean one may be less than pleased about his masterwork’s meteoric rise, but the two share a flimsy alliance nonetheless.
A unique combination of shrewd military intellect and raw brute strength has ascended Ghoritch to Clan Moulder’s most exalted military rank.
Ghoritch has always dominated Hell Pit’s blood-soaked arenas and now oversees his successors, keeping the other monsters fresh for war.
Giant snipping blades driven by Warpstone-driven pistons replace the Rat Ogre claws of Ghoritch’s heavily modified host body.
Masterful field surgery techniques and hastily administered steroid shots keep wounded monsters alive and keen to maximise the slaughtering.
As Moulder’s most frightening battlefield presence, Throt primes his combat capabilities to bring down the toughest monsters of war himself.
“Take-hoard ALL body part-bits, yes-yes! No organ goes to waste!”
Several self-developmental experiments have radically sped up Throt’s metabolism, preventing fatigue but making him mindlessly ferocious when hungry.
Clan Moulder command the hardiest monsters in all Skavendom, but the fear of a violent throttling makes Throt’s critters that little bit tougher!
The Warpstone shard embedded in Throt’s left eye socket feeds its baleful influence directly into his brain, giving him added strength.
Every twig, stick, branch and trunk of Athel Loren is infused with the awesome power of nature in its rawest form.
A robust and otherworldly vintage, with a distinctly spellbinding aftertaste.
All shall love me, and despair.
Ariel's handmaidens are imbued with the boundless energy of spring.
The Queen of the Asrai rarely commands armies, but those she empowers to lead the Deepwood Host do so with illustrious authority.
Ariel's magics interweave with those of her sorcerous acolytes, infusing the air with a harmony of power.
By Isha’s otherworldly influence, the Winds blow fortuitously across lands where her children need it the most.
Ariel is a conduit of deific power, capable of wielding spellcraft as if she herself were the Goddess of Nature.
The Mother’s demeanour is one of a wholesome Elven maiden, both of great beauty and bounteous lifeforce.
Ariel becomes ever more warlike as the decline of the natural world continues, thus perpetuating her dangerous, mothlike form.
The Queen in the Woods influences every acre of her realm, her lifeforce ever intertwined with the forest itself.
Wherever Ariel treads, trees and vegetation are compelled to spring forth to provide sustenance and haven for her kin.
If the glades are to survive these dark times, the Queen needs champions willing and able to put other lands to the sword.
Once the foremost of the Elven magi who first settled Athel Loren’s glades, now an all-powerful Mage Queen of deep prophetic wisdom.
Many believe Drycha lost her mind when Morghur’s blood was spilt amongst the roots of the once-glorious creature known as the Tree of Woe.
Those at forest fringes where the Wargrove is known to dwell gather anything but deadwood at their peril!
After years examining the Elves’ every action, the Briarmaven knows how to exploit their strengths as well as their weaknesses.
The verdant labyrinth of the forest unsettles even the most courageous soul.
The Ancients’ former handmaidens were once the forest’s overseers, taming the Winds to bring sustenance to bough and branch – that time will come again.
Many are the spirits Drycha believes have been failed by the Asrai, their names remembered by the enchantments of her unending mantra.
Naestra possesses lethality in her precision, and Arahan exuberance in her bladework, both fighting zealously in the forest’s name.
Armour is just a formality when you're as hard as nails and as tough as old boots.
Death is always just a shot away.
Naestra and Arahan do not shirk the bitter press of melee, moving swiftly to the fray should the situation require it.
Such is the twins’ bond that the harms inflicted on one are inconsequential so long as the other yet draws breath.
Regardless of their mysterious origins, all Elves know Naestra and Arahan speak with the authority of their beloved Mage Queen.
A dedicated sentinel of all that the Asrai hold dear, Naestra seeks battle only in pursuit of preventing greater harms.
Like an unbridled flame, Arahan lives for destruction, welcoming battle with wanton joy.
The sky’s fauna adore Naestra, doing as she wills out of love, while fearing Arahan and doing as she wills out of respect.
The sisters walk paths that even Waywatchers dread, treading the Dreaming Wood as if it were the eternally sunlit groves of Arranoc.
Whenever the twins present Lord Daith with a new challenge, he simply gives a small smile and returns to the fires of the forge.
Never before has a Beastmen leader proved so elusive to retribution.
In the gloomy depths of the Drakwald Forest, Khazrak has his pick of primal warriors to add to his multiplying warherd.
The lesser beasts of Khazrak’s hordes are driven into such a slavering frenzy that all flesh and bone are quickly stripped from their victims.
From his most favoured enemies come the most favoured of trophies.
Khazrak is an unusual beast; his deep cunning and propensity for carefully planned ambushes makes him a wily foe.
The Dark Omen twists the Winds to both savage his enemies and empower his hordes.
Malagor's profanities are so great that no other Bray-Shaman would dare enact them. Despite this, the foolish and insane attempt a fraction of his works.
He is the devil rendered in woodcut in ancient tomes kept under lock and key, lest the terrible secrets within blast the sanity of any who read them.
Morghur's approach darkens the sky, rots the land, and twists all life that it touches.
Profanity after profanity, Morghur bestows curses and blessings unto his horde. Those who live bring new mishappen limbs and damned powers to bear.
Beyond the malaise of his presence, Morghur's corrupting touch can unmake a man, leaving him less than he was. Less than nothing.
I came here hoping to take it all back. I came hoping to look upon the far deeps, on the ancestor statues of the Abyss of Iron’s Dream...
Belegar's vengeful Ancestors impart an ember of their ancient rage within his forces, driving them to feats of incredible stalwartness.
Lightweight, compact or simply equipped with the right tools for the job, Belegar's forces are particularly experienced in underground warfare.
The throng is overtaken with gnollengrom with a fervour not seen since ages past!
Grombrindal’s mere presence drives the Dawi to feats that even the grumbliest Longbeard would laud!
Grombrindal is never late, nor ever early – he arrives precisely when needed the most.
It is unclear how Grombrindal came to be, but his long history of appearances suggest he has crossed the bounds of mortality.
The world changes for the worse; the usual prudence of the Engineers Guild must be tempered! Even they would not deny the White Dwarf!
The Bloodbeast marches to war with his towering Minotaurs in tow, the land left scarred and bleeding in his stampeding wake.
Already an accomplished hunter when Chaos came to the world, Oxyotl mounted countless bold ambushes with his spawn-kin against the oncoming hordes.
Pugnacious and stubborn, the war beasts that pull these ramshackle chariots are grotesque combinations of great boar and mighty ram.
Pugnacious and stubborn, the war beasts that pull these ramshackle chariots are grotesque combinations of great boar and mighty ram.

A brutally simple weapon makes the Doombull’s incredible punching power more than enough to puncture armour and cause dreadful injury.
All horned Fathers of Rage encapsulate the raw will of the Dark Masters – they are strong, determined, and incredibly hard to kill.
Though no master of strategy or battle doctrine, a Doombull is still capable of leadership, particularly over their own kin.
To lead a horned army’s charge is to gore the first foe, then immediately seek to maim all others with an axe’s reach.
The bellowing call of the Doombull resounds for miles around, invoking the intense bloodlust that runs through all their kind.
Those strong enough to tame the powerful, unruly Razorgors can harness them for chariots.

A palpable miasma of fell sorcery surrounds the Bray-Shaman, distorting and maiming reality.
Shamans do not generally engage in physical combat themselves, instead sending out their spirit to possess a suitably monstrous surrogate.
Bray-Shamans speak the will of the Dark Gods, and those that defy them pay the highest price of all.
Impenetrably matted fur and grim trinkets make the Bray-Shamans more than just vile to behold, but incredibly hard to injure.
By the Bray-Shaman’s incantations, those lesser in body or mind have their hair and fur clogged into impervious hides.
In the right hands the braystaff is not just a symbol of position or conduit of magic, but also a brutal weapon.
In frenzied ritual celebration the Bray-Shaman invokes the Dark Gods’ power to infuse the herds with bestial strength.
Those strong enough to tame the powerful, unruly Razorgors can harness them for chariots.
Pugnacious and stubborn, the war beasts that pull these ramshackle chariots are grotesque combinations of great boar and mighty ram.

This Lord speaks with a dread booming voice – a gift from his Dark Masters to ensure obedience.
To many, the vilified Crowfather is a harbinger of the downfall of all they hold dear.
Under a scarlet moon, Taurox drank deep from the bloody river of his own creation to gain a most unholy vitality.
The crimson stream flowing at the Bloodbeast’s hooves betokens his unfathomable thirst for slaughter, ever drenching him in freshly spilled blood.
Khorne grants multitudinous gifts for the purposes of war, but Taurox’s gift is perhaps the greatest of any one Beastman.
The need for fresh red meat is not driven by hunger for sustenance, but the unholy exhilaration of consuming an enemy’s flesh.
The question is not "Who would let him destroy the world?", it’s "Who can even stop him?"
The impenetrable masses of ancient, gnarled forests harbour even the most gargantuan horrors, lurking undetected until emerging to fill their maws.
Possessed by a singular, apocalyptic vision and utter hatred, this champion proliferates the Dark Gods' will.
Often operating their own battlefield manoeuvres, the unyielding Wargors maraud ahead of the warherd with their Bestigor retinues.
Certain lesser beasts thrive under a pack leader, if only just to charge them in the right direction to unleash their savagery.
Spurred forth by the bellowing Wargors, Beastmen chariots scatter all before them with hooves, horns and blades.
Day and night the Wargors brood and plot the myriad ways they can gain the upper hand over their victims.
Those strong enough to tame the powerful, unruly Razorgors can harness them for chariots.
Pugnacious and stubborn, the war beasts that pull these ramshackle chariots are grotesque combinations of great boar and mighty ram.
By which one greets grobi and urk alike.
While many engineers carry innumerable tools on their person, some espouse the art of carrying only five different protractors.
The deadly blast of the Grudge-raker inspires fear in even the most dimwitted creature.
Stand Back! These are Dawr, but this is only the milluzth attempt!
With this double-barreled, pellet-spewing device, one can riddle a single target or blast a swathe into oncoming troops.
Each round delicately crafted to deliver death with a personal touch.
In possession of countless irreplaceable tools and devices, no Master Engineer goes down without a fight!
Dwarfen craftsmanship ensures any weapon is infinitely more likely to run out of ammunition before succumbing to the stress of battle!
Bring the Barag forwards! Hand me that spyglass!
Dawi Rune Magic is potent, and damned hard to defend against!
Where the Anvil of Doom goes, so too does the Anvilguard, ever loyal and vigilant.
It must be perfect! Anything less is as good as useless!
When facing a rage like this it's usually safest to run in the opposite direction. And quickly.
The dense power exuded from the Anvil weighs heavily upon the minds of enemy Wizards.
Covered in the Runelord’s ancient script, the anvil has given form to the most powerful runic weapons ever forged.
If they were good enough for our glorious Ancestors, they're good enough for us!
Upon the Anvil of Doom the rune weapons of legend are forged.
Every new rune struck is a blow to our enemies!
The magic is strong in these runes, bound together by a true master.
By Gazul's will, the foul despoilers of the dead shall meet their justice!
From the Underearth I venture with Gazul's blessing, so that the spirits of the ancestors may rest in peace.
But can all the horrors of the world kill these mere mortals?
Burn away the darkness in the flames of conviction.
Thorek does not abide new technology, using ancient techniques to lend his council and strong arm to the cause of the old Dwarf Empire.
The ground crystals of Tzeentch's realm can imbue darts with the power to pierce any ward and find the weakest points on the most formidable foes.
Harvested from a rare flower found only in the most toxic corners of Nurgle's gardens, this poison ensures a long and painful death.
Oxyotl’s time was closer to an age of technological wonders, when the Lizardmen wielded the Old Ones’ untold devices of mysterious power.
Extinction is the rule. Survival is the exception.
A first-hand glimpse of the world’s fate – should Chaos succeed – is enough to know the fight against them must never falter.
The path back from the Chaos Realm passes through fell places that cannot be recounted, but also forgotten lands of wondrous creatures.
With nothing but instincts and cunning, Oxyotl survived the creatures of the Chaos Realm. In this realm, they will not survive him.
Time after time, Oxyotl’s enemies arrive to find him ensconced nearby, soon meeting their deaths in a hail of barbed darts.
The Oracle’s divining presence can anchor the impassiveness of the braves around him in the most heated of battles.
Spitting toxic bile, the Troglodon triangulates its victim’s location as the fluid sizzles upon searing flesh.
A vile wave indeed, the creeping things that nest in the decaying undergrowth swarm all over the foe.
Von Carstein. The Everchosen. Dead men. Exalted men. In their skin they are all still men. This...will be the Age of the Beast.
What the Gods gifted to me can be gifted to another. I will not be the one mind in a race of blunt, witless animals.
Despite his aspirations as a ruler, Throgg is no tin tyrant hiding behind foolish legions.
Wulfrik once pursued the path of a great warrior king, and for a time cursed the gods for denying him.
Wulfrik’s Gift of Tongues means no-one can deny him a duel, but he still delights in crude invectives to break his enemies’ spirits.
Men as great as the beasts they bring down.
Blending magic and metalwork, the Runesmith hones armour with greater solidity than items wrought by any other mortal race in the world.
Perhaps by some gift of Grungni, when a Runesmith feels the rage of battle his throng’s weapons glow with the heat of the forgefires.
One bound by an oath to defend fights all the harder, gladly giving his life rather than face the dishonour of failure.
Deep-tunnel warfare requires one to become comfortable standing closer to explosions than is perhaps sensible.
Long periods spent tracking foes far from the safety of the Holds makes experts at approaching enemies from unexpected angles.
Necromancy without peer; reanimation worthy of a king.
What greater prospect do I have in Nagash's service – a future of mindless servitude in an unchanging world? The Great Necromancer is a selfish child.
Kemmler does not hesitate to plunder barrows, pillage tombs, or desecrate ancient halls in his pursuit of knowledge.
Accursed relics from ancient barrows cleave the soul as easily as they part the flesh.
Even in Undeath, every queen needs loyal retainers and handmaidens.
Even in Undeath, every queen needs loyal retainers and handmaidens.
This one is no apprentice in the black arts but a master of Necromancy and Dark Magic.
Skill honed by centuries, strength tempered by blood.
It takes a combination of madness, desperation and an iron stomach to be levied alongside the living dead.
Skeletal Steeds draped in fine armour make for an impressive and dangerous sight.
Wight Kings require the steeds that bore them in life, and will do again in death.
The mighty Airship of the oathsworn Slayer and gifted Engineer Malakai Makaisson carries him into the fray against those who would dare to wage war against Dawi-kind, and Gotrek in particular!
Tamurkhan's utterly fearsome reputation walks, or rather slithers, before him.
This Lord's many deeds - both on and off the battlefield - have brought them renown among their allies and made them feared by their enemies.
Whether it be training harder, travelling lighter, eating less or sleeping better, there's always a way to draw more from the day.
Those in the army can find succour or be replenished by the power of this champion.

This champion extols discipline and fear away from the battlefield as much as on it.

Such a champion will not bend or break, but slay in their Lord's name.

Lying in wait, experienced and patient, striking when the foe least expects.

Deep devotion to the Bloody-handed God have led to his favour, enabling her to withstand more punishment in melee than others.

A gift from Khaine, containing the secret of eternal youth and beauty. His brides may bathe in it to renew their vitality.

This loyal Dawi can trace his lineage back to Valaya, Goddess of Healing and Protection.

Sitting around waiting for something to happen is not their style.
More than keen, this one is positively champing at the bit to get up and at the enemy.
A paragon of martial excellence, with few peers among their own kind, let alone the enemy.
Ever watchful, this one bides their time until precisely the right moment to attack.
As master of the foremost Asur mages, this Elf has studied in their secret libraries longer than most men live.
This body may be frail, but never doubt the strength of the mind, or the heart within it.
Rally to my banner, and we shall bathe the plains with the blood of our enemies!
Self-important and opinionated, this one's hubris knows no end.
Self-effacing and unpresuming, he believes that we all have a part to play in the Great Plan, one way or another.
As the last remaining warrior of the now ruined temple-city of Xhotl, for Kroq-Gar the battle is not yet over.
Oldest and most powerful of the living Mage-Priests, Mazdamundi is a figure of awe even amongst his own kind.
What are you even for? You're not part of the Great Plan, like all your kind.
The Plan is the Plan. We shall not deviate or retreat from its path.
Yes, yes, Queek's plan, Queek's triumph. Others just following orders. Grovel before glorious Lord Queek!
I keep them sharp, yes-yes. Always ready for the challenge that I know is coming, yes-yes!
When they come for you, go straight for the throat and tear it clean out. They won't come again.
Rather than weakening with age, Lord Skrolk is possessed with a diabolic vitality that belies the years and the heaped diseases he carries.
By their very nature, rats are very sneaky - even sneakier than Goblins. In fact, they're probably the sneakiest of all.
Most precious of all substances, the pulse of our life.
Glory in your dark majesty, my lord.
Vampires and their liche-servants are devious creatures; manipulative with many mortal servants in their thrall.
They will tremble, my lord, oh, they will fear!
Once forbidden knowledge is acquired, Necromancers and Vampires will jealously guard it from rivals' eyes.
A master indeed - to rival the Great Necromancer himself?
Those whom the Mage Queen has favoured fight as if powered by her hand.
The first arrow of battle must fly truest.
This Lord's many deeds - both on and off the battlefield - have brought them renown among their allies and made them feared by their enemies.
This Lord's many deeds - both on and off the battlefield - have brought them renown among their allies and made them feared by their enemies.
The largest, most aggressive creatures - usually the oldest bulls of the herd - must be directed, lest their independent spirit lead them astray.
You need to be at the very centre of this pack of furious monsters to have the minutest chance of controlling their rage. Good luck!
It is a great honour to direct the elite warriors who protect the Plan from calamity.
The most intelligent hunter tends to move swiftly up the chain of command.
The unforgiving law of the jungle is most clear on matters of ascendancy.
Only the finest beast riders can hang on whilst their mounts crash through the jungle undergrowth or smash through the foe's ranks.
A long-serving member of an ancient, honourable tradition.
This seasoned warrior understands irregular combat perfectly: when to attack, when to hold back, when to withdraw behind heavier lines.
Mount and rider, together as one at their very cores. Indivisible.
Braves who emerge from the same spawning often share a deep connection – a bond which provides considerable advantages in battle.
Whilst one brother lives in darkness, the other, his double-twin, exists in light. Behold!
Cousin of darkness, Huanchi's priests too shall dwell in twilight.
Creator-meld of the beast, Itzl be praised!
By your scales be you blessed by the divine protector.
Brother of Great Tlazcotl, Tepok of the Air shall always be honoured. Let it be done.
The universe resides within his reflective eyes; embrace the coldness of blessed certainty.
All shall be one, as it is written.
Contemplation is the path to alignment, to the correct interpretation of the Great Plan.
Through millennia of study, total mastery over magic may be attained.
Within the Slann's gaze shines the cold-blooded scrutiny of the Old Ones.
Everywhere we shine, death and life burn into something new…
The power of the Old Ones, stored for future use so that - at precisely the right time - the Great Plan may be advanced.
Cold, merciless, without pity, obeying only logic. Hardened against magic's ill-effects.
When wounded, the Slann's sheer force of will literally recombines his body.
The Mage-Priest's thought patterns are so alien that they are even beyond the perception of enemy Wizards.
The Plan *will* be observed, even if every member of the younger races has to die to achieve the Old Ones' goals.
Those Saurus not lost to war may live to a great age - their long service esteemed and respected by younger Lizardmen hungry for experience.
Those Saurus not lost to war may live to a great age - their long service esteemed and respected by younger Lizardmen hungry for experience.
Orders must be followed and the chain of command honoured; only then will the Great Plan be served.
The relentlessly-bloodthirsty Children of Chaos do not deserve a place in the Old Ones' perfect world.
The insidious Rat-spawn, who dare threaten Lustria's temple-cities with their vile plagues, must be wiped from its hallowed shores.
The vicious cruelty of the Druchii has no place within the Great Plan and must be stamped out at all costs.
Resolutely not part of the Great Plan, the disgusting Greenskins are a stain on the surface of the world.
The self-serving, insular Dawi must all be killed if balance is to be restored to the world.
Dark, feral beasts indigenous to Lustria, tempted from their tropical jungles to bear the Lizardmen to battle.
Grymloq is Kroq-Gar's ageless Carnosaur, upon which the great Lizardman Lord has won all his many victories.
Very rare and virtually extinct, even in Lustria, the Horned One's preternatural swiftness puts it way ahead of other Cold Ones.
Once before, the Ancient Enemy unmade the Great Plan. It shall not be permitted to do so again.
The dead should dead remain, never to rise again and trouble the living.
Mankind has developed in a direction not in keeping with the tenets of the Great Plan; they must be stopped.
The City of Destiny withstood the Ancient Enemy's infernal onslaught for centuries; subsequent spawnings have magical resistance to physical attack.
Lizardmen can move with deceptive speed and agility when they have to.
Life in the jungle means knowing the difference between which flora can heal and what, if ingested, will kill you.
The power generated by the overarching Geomantic Web can also be used to nourish the Saurus on the march.
The largest Stegadon to be found anywhere, Zlaaq has served Lord Mazdamundi faithfully for almost five hundred years.
Of course, those who live to kill must also kill to live...
Across the gulf of space, the serene Potec has shared the secrets of time so that the Lizardmen may protect themselves against supernatural attack.
The ultimate jungle hunters, these large, apex predators have terrorised the primordial jungles since the dawn of existence.
Dark, feral beasts indigenous to Lustria, tempted from their tropical jungles to bear the Lizardmen to battle.
The ultimate jungle hunters, these large, apex predators have terrorised the primordial jungles since the dawn of existence.
Dark, feral beasts indigenous to Lustria, tempted from their tropical jungles to bear the Lizardmen to battle.
The jungle flora harbours the Lizardmen's microscopic allies in the war that never ends.
Some Lizardmen are able to seamlessly blend in with their jungle environment in order to observe, or defend themselves from, their enemies.
Mighty, horned, reptilian beasts, Stegadons are naturally armoured with bony scales and spikes protruding from their crests.
Dangerous predators with sharp talons and pointed beaks, these giant flying reptiles are surprisingly agile and can spot their prey at great distances.
Whereby the terrain itself is both shield and weapon, enabling the Lizardmen to both mask their numbers and surprise the foe.
Mighty, horned, reptilian beasts, Stegadons are naturally armoured with bony scales and spikes protruding from their crests.
Dangerous predators with sharp talons and pointed beaks, these giant flying reptiles are surprisingly agile and can spot their prey at great distances.
Mighty, horned, reptilian beasts, Stegadons are naturally armoured with bony scales and spikes protruding from their crests.
Dangerous predators with sharp talons and pointed beaks, these giant flying reptiles are surprisingly agile and can spot their prey at great distances.
The power to move objects without touching them makes missiles attacks against this one largely pointless.
With a mighty bellow, the caster invokes Corvus the Crow Lord, summoning his servants to peck at the foe's eyes.
Calling upon the beast spirits of the wild, the caster sheathes vulnerable flesh in unyielding fur and hide.
Sounding a gnarled horn, the caster summons a glowing amber spear and hurls it at the foe with uncanny accuracy.
Nebulous nature spirits assail the foe, clawing at them with hands not nearly as insubstantial as they appear.
Kadon, a master of forms, was able to shift his shape into anything he chose. This mastery is used to summon a Manticore, as if Kadon himself fights for you.
The spellcaster unleashes the beast within, using its fury to transform allies into bestial forms.
With a mighty bellow, the caster invokes Corvus the Crow Lord, summoning his servants to peck at the foe's eyes.
With a mighty bellow, the caster invokes Corvus the Crow Lord, summoning his servants to peck at the foe's eyes.
Trees live for thousands of years and have very long memories. When called to fight, centuries of pent-up wrath are unleashed.
The Wizard draws wholesome energies from the soil, imbuing companions with the natural resilience of the earth.
This spell temporarily transforms allies' mortal flesh into unbreakable rock, increasing tenfold their resistance to attack.
By speaking Druthandor's name the Wizard is able to heal allies' injuries much faster than by natural means.
Prickly gorse bursts from the ground around the caster's allies, protecting them from attack like a spiky, living shield.
This spell causes gnarled, fibrous hands to emerge from beneath the ground, dragging the foe to a claustrophobic, suffocating end.
When cast this spell enfeebles enemy minds; they feel the crushing weight of reality bearing down upon them.
When cast this spell enfeebles enemy minds; they feel the crushing weight of reality bearing down upon them.
The caster weaves a confounding fog that numbs and deludes enemies, causing them to stumble and stagger.
The caster weaves a confounding fog that numbs and deludes enemies, causing them to stumble and stagger.
The caster weaves a confounding fog that numbs and deludes enemies, causing them to stumble and stagger.
The supernatural solution is often the best; weapons materialise before the caster's allies, allowing them to slice through flesh, soul, and consciousness.
A spectral pendulum is summoned by the Wizard. On command, it swings, razor sharp and with lethal speed, through the foe.
The spellcaster opens a vortex leading into the Pit. Anything caught within it will be lost forever.
The Wizard destroys their enemies from within, corroding foes' minds with doubt and crisis.
This spell unleashes a howling roar of such intensity that it mashes brains and bursts eyeballs.
The Bray-Shaman magnifies the savage and animalistic parts of the foe's psyche until they are no more than growling beasts.
Ghorok was a legendary Minotaur, ferocious as a storm. His spirit-mantle is terrible and dangerous to the bearer.
The Bray-Shaman sends his mind into the wilds, possessing the largest creature he can find and storming back with a vengeance.
A red-hot spear of wrath is driven into enemy mounts' wild hearts, causing them to turn upon their riders.
Each Black Ark is a fortress-city without peer. Throwing oneself unto its Black-Stone defences is folly without equal.
The Black Ark provides near-limitless access to pristine arms and armour, each raiding party clad in the finest forgework.
The presence of a powerful Sorceress upon the Black Ark provides opportunities to weave the darkest magecraft.
This one's intimate knowledge of the inner workings of Skaven machinery enables him to improve their efficiency on the battlefield.
To rise above the rank and file, to claw one's way above the mire and the filth, takes a certain, superior breed of Skaven.
Is it better to be respected or feared? What sort of question is that... why, both of course!
Early years spent in the gutter both prepares the ambitious rat for power and schools him in the dirtier, more cut-throat ways of war.
This one has seen the hideous deformities created by Clan Moulder firsthand and now fancies himself a dab hand with a needle and thread…
Potions infused with Warpstone transmogrify the not-always-willing testbed subjects; those who survive the process emerge stronger and better in every way.
Having to hide, for an extended period, in a dark, dank recess, in order to entrap and kill your target encourages lateral thinking.
The wise commander considers the lash a dear friend - so much more than a motivational tool to encourage correctness in spirit and behaviour.
This one knows just what to say to 'encourage' the very best work from his underling Warp-smiths and technicians.
Knowing exactly where and when to strike is essential when fielding fiendish, potentially battle-winning plague-weapons.
The poisoned knife is assurance of the target's removal from the game, and from the world also.
Naturally, rats get in everywhere – even the tiniest opening presents little obstacle – spreading their disease and corruption everywhere they can.
Keeping on top of things with an iron fist prevents Skavendom from becoming too much of a degenerate mess.
When making corpses of your foes, leave nothing of value for their kin to recover.
As you might expect, the forces of order are repelled by the Skaven and their myriad disgusting, disease-ridden ways.
Whether by attachment or mutation, something nasty and spiky on your tail has got to bring no little advantage in battle.
If you've got the Warptokens and the contacts, you can get all manner of fine, murderous armaments crafted to fit claw or tail perfectly.

The fact that the Warlock Engineers sell to all sides in the constant Skaven struggle for dominance is well-known; the fact that for a very high price they offer to withhold their services is widely guessed.
This blade is attached to a Warp-generator that channels crackling energy along the weapon.
A Warpstone-enchanted breastplate and a thick steel helmet are useful to protect the wearer from shrapnel.
All Skaven are unprincipled and untrustworthy by their foul natures. However, this is rarely a disadvantage in the face of the enemy.
Furtive, scheming, sly, cunning, underhand, devious, conniving, double-dealing, and sneaky - valuable traits if you wish to stay alive!
An unholy battle altar dedicated to the Great Horned Rat, its ominous tolling strikes awe into evil Skaven hearts and fear into their opponents.
An unholy battle altar dedicated to the Great Horned Rat, its ominous tolling strikes awe into evil Skaven hearts and fear into their opponents.
This altar, ridden with disease, is a fitting pulpit from which the Plague Priests preach their words of poison and death.
When you're clearly the better than the rest, others are mere puppets to be toyed with along the way and then casually sacrificed.
Only the strongest, fiercest, and most ruthless may become members of the most elite claw-unit of all.
No act, no matter how despicable, is considered taboo when you're on the way to the very top.
Being untrustworthy and treacherous tends to make one suspicious of others.
Yes-yes, I will kill-kill all day and through the night until the next. They will all die and then the Council will see my worth, yes-yes!
Oft-times, in order to get your point across, it is necessary to violently kill associates as an example to the others, that they may learn.
Stench upon pox upon malady; so foul is the Skrolk's putrefaction that only the most serious devotees can stand to be in his presence.
The hideous countenance that this one presents is an affront to nature and a true sign of the Great Horned Rat's limitless power.
Plants wither and die when this one passes by, so utterly disease-ridden is he.
The best-laid plans – those involving murder with poison and knives – must remain secret, under pain of a hideous death involving poison and knives...
Skaven society is a tyranny moderated by assassination; this one is its ambassador.
If you wish to expand into new territory, it helps to head-up a voracious, colonising force that breed like… er, oh!
It should be no surprise that a race without a shred of honour or decency between them have even less regard for each other's lives.
All the hate, envy, and malice uttered in prayer each day, returned a thousand-fold.
As an aid to spellcasting, they are peerless. It is highly dangerous, of course, but a sure-fire route to limitless power.
A specially-engineered breed of Rat Ogre, the Bonebreaker has a braced platform strapped or bolted to its back for carrying a Skaven Warlord to battle.
No beast can truly be controlled, but these desperate contrivances bring the smallest semblance of order.
A general's horse can be their most trusted and daring companion. Just don't name him 'Daisy'.
An Imperial pegasus is a noble, winged steed, intelligent and loyal.
While Wizards can rarely benefit from armour, a warhorse does offer some degree of protection and manoeuvrability.
This stinky hog is as grumpy and fierce as its brutal rider.
This enormous, revolting Arachnarok Spider shrine upon which the Shaman is borne forces even the branches of nearby trees to twist in revulsion at its diabolical passing.
Perfectly at home in the saddle, this warrior can ride at full-pelt through terrain others would struggle with on foot.
Following the example of the Doomstar, this warrior specializes in devastating, demoralizing strikes from the sky.
A member of the Wardancer kindred, this warrior fights to Loec's silent song.
This warrior has patrolled the borders of the Wildwood, facing down horrors unknowable and standing unfazed.
Fly on your wings, like an eagle. Touch the sun. Track the foe, ambush, and defeat.
With its magnificent frame and the great plumes of steam of its snorting breath, the Great Stag instils unflinching valour into those who ride it.
The God of the Hunt freely gifts his deific zeal for war to all nobles deemed worthy of their responsibilities to Athel Loren.
Longbow kinbands are regimented and resourceful when defending their forest homes, advancing and retreating like leaves in a storm.
While Lokhir prowls the land, his closest lieutenant takes command of the Blessed Dread.
In the wild, there is no such thing as good and evil, only predators and prey.
The Beastmasters were so preoccupied with whether or not they could, they didn't stop to think if they should.
What need is there to feed creatures perfectly capable of feeding themselves?
Extracting the claws of captive Harpies without suffering injury requires a control that few Beastmasters possess, but yields armaments most useful for beast-catching.
Some beasts are only tamed, or dominated, by some manner of being an order of magnitude stronger, in will if not in muscle.
No creature outmatches the Black Dragon Bracchus in terms of sheer cruelty and the ability to inflict pain, save for Rakarth himself!
The roar of a Manticore is guaranteed to send mortals fleeing, for they know a creature of terror is abroad.
Dark Elf Beastmasters roam the wilds atop their dreaded chariots, armed with barbed nets and harpoons to slay the foe and ensnare their prey.
They're lethal at eight months, and I do mean lethal. I've hunted most things that can hunt you, but the way these things move…
The greatest of all Beastmasters has no equal in his craft, commanding the wild and feral with almost supernatural aptitude.
The ancient archives of Ghrond contain secrets that can preserve life - or annihilate it.
Visions cloud the mind, prophesising the arrival of the enemy and uncovering every shadow in which they lurk.
The favour of Khorne is earned in blood and the brutal decimation of His foes.
The chosen of the Blood God leave burning cities in their wake, exerting Khorne's savage dominion over the mortal plane.
The armies of the Urfather spread their sickness with glee, earning Grandfather Nurgle's approval with every new infection.
Create a nightmare of decay, and let the Plague Lord feast on the suffering and sickness that follows.
A handsome hero is sure to tempt many, drawing the unwitting into the Prince of Pleasure's fold.
As the Perfect Prince's dark influence increases, so too do the blessings of His pleasure.
Fate remains in flux, ever changing under Tzeentch's influence and the workings of His heroes.
Tzeentch's authority is absolute, for infinite change is the very nature of Chaos.
The warriors of Ruin rely on great Heroes, to usher in a new age of anarchy.
Chaos magic consumes the land, hastening the spreading influence of Ruin.
The dominion of Chaos grows larger each day; soon the whole world will be under its sway.
The Ruinous Powers tighten their grip on the land, as dark sorcery paves the way for their fell influence.
As dark wings take to the skies and Daemon arrows bear down, the enemies of Chaos know their end is near.
To supplicate the Damned Prince is not only to worship him, but to follow in his immaculate footsteps.
“…From the day You were Chosen\\nAll wrongdoing found You,\\nFilled with lawlessness and sin,\\nYet perfect in Your ways…”
Fine silks bedecked with alluring jewels of malevolent magic empower this statuesque form.
One cannot experience the greatest pleasures without first experiencing the greatest pains.
Long and delicate, Azazel’s double-headed tail suspends with graceful movements, belying its potential to lacerate with extreme violence.
Beneath flax-fine hair and a crown of lacquered horns sit eyes full of innocence; and yet they are cruel, calculating and without pity.
Self-medicating himself with infection, the Doctor instigates symptoms upon his own body that amplify his vitality.
With the Leechlord’s brilliant mind on his side, Nurgle brings more and more thralls of Chaos under his sway.
As impermanent as life, cleanliness is merely a blank slate upon which the feculent stain of disease can be smeared.
“Resilience cannot be achieved without affliction! The healthiest fighters are always the blightest!”
As Nurgle’s worldly dominion grows, so too does the splendour of His Garden of Blight and the power of His Champions.
Nurgle not only grants Festus the knowledge to cultivate all the mortal world’s pathogens, but also those of countless other realities.
The brand of the Blood God has been seared into the skin, a symbol of abject brutality.
A dedicated warrior of Khorne knows no joy but the thrill of battle and bloodshed.
What magic can penetrate the searing hatred within the minds of the Blood God's most brutal followers.
For one fighting with the favour of the Ruinous Powers, glory and riches come naturally.
The fire of hate burns rapidly across the land, turning all in its path to ash and cinder.
Whole civilisations will be flooded by infection, as its spread spins wildly out of control.
Few could resist such sultry wiles, drawing so many to corruption's insidious grasp.
There is no greater glory than to instigate a tide of change and watch it sweep across the world.
All will bow before such a harbinger of pure, unbridled Chaos, oozing with the energies of corruption.
No act of faith can rival reaving the souls of the slain; a dark and twisted offering in honour of the Ruinous Powers.
You will serve me, wretch, or you will die, there is no other option.
Few experiences match the satisfaction of shattering the bones of one's enemies.
The Chaos Gods grant almighty strength to the most fervent among their faithful.
The Warriors of Chaos bear the brunt of every attack with a stoic endurance, unburdened by the fear of pain.
Those bearing the mark of Nurgle exude a sickening miasma wherever they go.
How exactly does one injure further the decayed, rotting flesh of the Urfather's servants?
The armies of Nurgle find strength in decay, bolstered by their own festering wounds.
Come closer, sweet morsels… Why fight when you can simply surrender to temptation?
Grace and speed are second nature to those bearing the Mark of Slaanesh.
For those branded by the Prince of Pleasure, even a military charge is an artful display of elegance and beauty.
Magic and Chaos are eternally intertwined in a symbiotic storm of malevolent power.
Magic need not only wreak havoc at range—half the fun of battle, after all, is seeing the fear in your enemy's eyes.
The Forsaken heed the commands of the powerful, and thrive on the excess of their energy.
When enemies gaze into the eyes of insanity, insanity has a way of gazing back.
The Eagle protects me, for I am but a vessel of change!
The Winds of Magic twist and churn around Tzeentch's almighty Paragons of Change.
Kill, crush, destroy—these are the tenets of Chaos!
Pain is a trivial price to pay in assuring the complete annihilation of Order!
The brand of the Ruinous Powers is seared into the skin, a mark of absolute dedication to the cause of corruption.
Nothing drains the enemy’s fight like ritualistic executions of severed ribs and exposed lungs strewn across bloody backs.
Only the worthiest achieve glory in Valkia’s presence, knowing that Khorne watches her closely and despises cowards.
The legend of Valkia’s ill-fated tribe is known throughout the north, a vestige of her lost humanity eradicated in bloody vengeance.
The repair of Valkia’s mortal frame was but a prelude to Khorne’s gift of godly vitality.
While the craven sneak to their death, the brave live on.
By the indomitable will of the God of Warriors, His chosen queen will not be allowed to die.
As a twisted fusion of diabolic strength and sorcery, Vilitch owes all to the God of Change, and stands against any who would oppose Him.
Tugging at the loose strands in the minds of enemies and allies alike, Vilitch bends all to his will.
Take it all and find more still! Everything is not enough!
Yes, yes, you can have them back when I'm done with them.
With the body of a brute and the skills of a sorcerer, every strike is imbued with mighty strength and vile magics.
The Forsaken flock to Vilitch, basking in the aura of flux that swirls around the Twisted Twin.
No mortal host shall hold them back.
Where 'battle' is the question, 'violent rage' is undoubtedly the answer.
Hatred is such a simple emotion, and one so easy for mortals to be consumed by.
The Teeth of Death clamp down hard upon their target, spurred on by the urgings of their Prince.
Through the grotesque blessings of Nurgle, virulent pus absorbs every incoming blow.
The hordes of decay are endless, creeping across the land like a repulsive plague of death.
A viscous, burning acid spurts wildly from bulbous pustules, corroding through flesh and bone.
An enchanting scent clouds the air, epitomising the tantalising allure of Slaanesh.
The rewards of pleasure are vast indeed, enough to tempt even the most stoic of souls.
Armies fall before the Daemonettes of Slaanesh, lulled into a drowsy haze by the enticing aroma flooding their senses.
The wings of the Raven God raise his faithful high, surrounding them with arcane energies.
The thirst for knowledge is a dark and endless pit, likely to swallow all sanity whole.
The arcane fire of Tzeentch shall never be quenched!
An aura of pure malevolence crackles and burns with energy, exuded from only those truly steeped in Chaos.
Glory will be mine—my ascendance is inevitable!
The Ruinous Powers stand unified in only one pursuit; the stark and utter destruction of Order.
Slaanesh's favoured champions are so attractively captivating that few can find the will to raise a blade against them.
From a warm, silvery voice comes whispers telling the foe of pleasures that could be theirs, if only they submit to the waiting arms of Slaanesh.
These rune-etched collars, imbued with Khorne's loathing for magic, provide protection against the arcane arts.
The champion is surrounded by crackling flames that burn his enemies whilst leaving his own body untouched.
A Chaos Familiar memorises spells on its master's behalf, constantly rehearsing for its big moment until it is called upon to share its arcane knowledge.
Fatigue is no issue when one is driven by the darkest rage imaginable.
Those blessed by Chaos see not only what is before them, but also what lurks in shadow, hiding in the periphery.
Working tirelessly to propagate disease, famine and decay, the Leechlord honours his unholy pact with the Lord of Pestilence.
The champion has been rewarded with a hideous appearance, grotesque enough to wither the hearts of men.
Granted skin as strong as iron plate, there is little that can penetrate the champion's defences.
Nurgle's Rot is the most dreaded and contagious of all diseases, for it gnaws at the victim's soul as well as his mortal body.
The champion's skin is covered with a thousand reptilian scales, each as tough as Dragonhide.
Enemies break like brittle twigs beneath the onslaught of such overwhelming strength.
Some are blessed by a dark understanding, able to gleam knowledge from every experience.
A third eye opens in the favoured one's forehead that can see the shifting strands of fate.
A foe may strike fast, but those evolved by Chaos move faster still.
The champion can channel the dark strength flowing through his veins to deliver a single blow that can shatter a fortress wall.
Born a warrior, lived as a queen, and died as a legend, Valkia now spills blood without need of sleep, respite or sustenance.
Vilitch leeches strength from everything around him just as easily as he leeches the very willpower from his drooling brother.
The dread carriages of the Ruinous hosts are more than just machines of war; they are symbols of status and power.
The dread steeds of Chaos are more than mere horses, but creatures tainted by Daemon blood, said to be gifts from the Dark Gods themselves.
A massive construction of hell-forged metal, mutant beast and jagged blade, ridden to war only by the bloodthirsty.
Mighty beasts of groaning iron and brass, taller than a man and possessed of a crushing mass.
The dread carriages of the Ruinous hosts are more than just machines of war; they are symbols of status and power.
The dread steeds of Chaos are more than mere horses, but creatures tainted by Daemon blood, said to be gifts from the Dark Gods themselves.
The dread steeds of Chaos are more than mere horses, but creatures tainted by Daemon blood, said to be gifts from the Dark Gods themselves.
As part of the binding ritual, Screamer bodies are flattened and transmuted into unlikely aspects.
A vast, mobile altar allows the souls of the slain to be ritualistically condemned directly from the field of slaughter.

Secret skill that automatically levels up as the character progresses and reduces cost of Path to Glory
Robes? Fool! We're going to battle, not a ball. Hand me my armour! ARMOUR!
Spell after spell, grant the enemy no reprieve!
Magic is little threat to one so well-versed in its dark and terrible intricacies.
Standing face to face with your enemy means getting to watch the light fade from their eyes when you win.
Every dark army requires a particularly twisted mind, capable of thinking three steps ahead of the enemy.
A leader is needed on the field of battle, able to rally the forces of Chaos in even the most dire situations.
No magic can deter one driven by the murderous force of fury.
Sacrifice in the Blood God's name, and soak in the blessings of his favour!
The raging fire of hate manifests itself in battle, immolating enemies in its smouldering heat.
Succumb to pestilence! Let Grandfather Nurgle feed on your suffering!
Such a reeking and repulsive stench might kill every enemy before combat even commences.
Acidic ichor corrodes through enemy armour, leaving them vulnerable to the fatal strike.
There's a dark and haunting beauty about such devastating impact, as bodies fall helplessly in tandem.
Victims can only stop and stare as the wickedly beautiful hordes charge them down.
When the energies of life are draining from the body, another's life energy will surely staunch the flow.
A barrier of Tzeentchian magic surrounds the warriors of the Changer, guarding them from the tumult of close combat.
Devastating bolts of arcane fire strike the earth, igniting all in their radius.
Sheathed in sorcery and guarded against attacks, the Spirit Warrior summons deadly flame.
A true tactician inspires all around them, encouraging allies to acts of vicious abandon.
Domination is the only goal, under the banner of Chaos Undivided.
Unleash pure Chaos at close quarters, slicing and dicing all within reach.
With a Daemonsmith’s incantation, a mere drop of Hashut’s purest ichor is enough to reduce entire cities to cinders and ash.
All in the path of this murderous rampage will have little chance to react before being trampled into a fine red mist.
By which even those born of fire and flame, deep within the forge, can be healed.
The enemy's fear; their blood spilt in the mud – these are the things that sustain me.
There is no greater thrill than to be in the midst of battle, slaughtering in Hashut's name.
Tuned to perfection in the broiling-hot machine shops of Zharr-Naggrund, this machine will get its occupants into the thick of it and out again, no matter the lay of the land.
Beneath their mutated faces and ever-darkened souls, the Chaos Dwarfs are still Dwarfs at heart, retaining all of their counterparts' metalworking skill and knack for ingenious engineering solutions.

From the barrels of the Chaos Dwarfs' infernal war machines are fired shrieking rockets and blasts of raw, Ruinous magick, leaving those not instantly turned to liquid quaking and gibbering in their wake.
Assuming you can't avoid the confrontation altogether, the most sensible course of action is to get well out of the way!
Even though they're considered little more than a raw resource by their evil masters, some Greenskins avoid being worked to death by "assisting" their keepers on the field of battle.
Wearing ultra-resilient armour forged with blood and hellfire, the Chaos Dwarfs present a  mighty defensive wall, stronger even than steel, to their incautious, overconfident enemies.
To be this effective in battle takes not just suicidal levels of courage and determination, but the discipline to hold the line and, as one, take the fight directly into the enemy's wavering hearts.
Though they face almost-certain death at the enemy's hands, that has to be better than what the Chaos Dwarfs have in store for their Greenskin underlings, right? Some even welcome such an end.
Drilling loading, shooting and reloading, until they become second nature, so the foe is under constant barrage, is surely the way to victory.
The Daemonic fire-elementals and various other monstrous creatures in the Chaos Dwarfs' service are fielded to crack the skulls and crush the souls of those who dare stand against them.
Those twisted, hellishly-mutated monsters in the service of the Chaos Dwarfs are some of their most effective weapons, particularly when organised into a malign host of Ruinous shock troops.
Now his once-great powers have waned, Ironhand's body is slowly succumbing to petrification. However, lopping off parts as they turn to stone only makes him stronger.
We will remake the world into our domain, a land of cinder-ash and the blackened bones of our enemies, until only we and those broken bodies that cower at our feet remain.
Hidden skill to grant Astragoth characters extra scaling
Through darkly enchanted means, Ironhand has gleaned great knowledge, certainly, but at the most terrible of costs.
Terrible powers are gained via terrible acts.
Only the strongest and best among his throng may serve Lord Astragoth.
Once his hands turned to stone, Astragoth had new, mechanical ones built and grafted to his body in their place, using all the twisted science at his disposal.
There are definitely some advantages to a body of stone: it makes one really hard to hurt, let alone kill!
Stronger, faster: better – it's not all woe when you're a bio-mechanical Dwarf Lord!
Every weakness, no matter how well hidden, is clear to Astragoth, as are many ways to exploit them to his own advantage.
In his mind Astragoth speaks for all the Chaos Dwarfs, for he is Zharr-Naggrund's legitimate ruler, and master of all he surveys.
Learn from the very best if you wish to become better.
Some warriors care not for their own personal safety, and so work themselves into a whirlwind of destruction and mindless violence!
As a Bull Centaur ages, their flesh hardens like metal – harder to hurt, quicker to heal, and better at resisting magical attack.
When that mist descends… Believe me, you don't want to be anywhere near this one, not if you value your worthless life!
None shall pass, at least not while this one breathes.
The Taur'ruk knows that although this one probably works for his rivals as well, they are without doubt truly loyal to him.
Countless conflicts and a keen sense of awareness have made this Lord difficult to entrap.
Deceit is a perfectly acceptable means of attack.
Beatings WILL continue until morale improves, or even if it does...
A Dawi-Zharr such as he does not care for being wounded – by his will alone he continues to fight.
Some conquerors are mild and fair. Not so this one, whose savagery and corruption truly know no bounds.
You will serve me, wretch, or you will die. There is no other option.
Proficient with figures, this Lord, or his subordinates, can keep his army fulfilled, even in dire circumstances.
To despoil, to corrupt and ruin, to break the mortals and take their gods from them – this is what Chaos wants.
Brutality or viciousness don't go anywhere near far enough. Even barbarism is too mild a term.
A modicum of care is just common sense when getting it wrong can find you trapped in another, infinitely worse dimension…
A modicum of care is just common sense when getting it wrong can find you trapped in another, infinitely worse dimension…
A modicum of care is just common sense when getting it wrong can find you trapped in another, infinitely worse dimension…
A modicum of care is just common sense when getting it wrong can find you trapped in another, infinitely worse dimension…
Wreathed in smoke, these huge, winged Daemonic-bulls are blessed with flesh that burns with the intensity of a living furnace that sparks the ground 'neath their hooves.
As creatures of flame and ash, the Red Bulls of Hashut cannot stray far from the Dark Lands, save for when the Winds of Magic – and Aqshy specifically – are at their strongest.
Believed to be a rare mutation of the Great Taurus, the magical Lammasu are the living embodiment of the Dark Land's rage, exhaling sorcerous clouds to protect their riders.
