By which the foe slowly turns to stone, beginning with the feet, so they are all too aware of their terrible fate as it gradually unfolds.
The mightiest warriors of the Legion of Azgorh smear their armour in the sacramental ash of the freshly-rendered dead.
The cinders and clinker from the grate beneath his sacrificial altar both heal Drazhoath and ward against magic.
Hidden skill to grant Drazhoath characters extra scaling
Truly their greed knows no bounds, as they strip the dead of every last scrap of dignity.
High up in the turrets of the Black Fortress, Drazhoath has waited, developing his sorcerous skills and biding his time.
A minor Daemonsmith no longer, Drazhoath has raised himself to greatness in his chosen field: to create the K'daai, half-raging fire, half-Daemon essence – all mindless destructive force.
The army's strength is bolstered by sorcerous means, channelled to power and protect its warriors.
This mighty Bale Taurus carries the dread Sorcerer Drazhoath the Ashen, Lord of the Black Fortress, to battle, at the head of his twisted Legion of Azgorh, to bring fire and Ruin down upon the foe.
Walls? I see only piles of sand crafted by children. Bring my brothers close enough and we shall take pleasure in fulfilling our bargain and topple them for you!
The border guards of the Chaos Dwarf realm are based at the ominous, imposing Black Fortress, wherein they stand watch over its many mines and caverns.
Almost killing as one, horrendous violence clearly runs in their blood.
Whether it be a sea of arrows, crackling blasts of magical energy or deadly war machines, being light on his feet has helped keep Gorduz and Da Gitz hold the lines against all comers.
Something is keeping Gorduz alive when he really should be dead in a ditch somewhere …or at least that's how it appears to literally *everyone* else.
Gorduz has caught someone trying to cheat him and goes into a fit of rage. Run, if you know what's good for you – as far and as fast as possible!
One of the factors in Gorduz' otherwise inexplicable longevity is his sheer, unrelenting aggression in the face of the enemy... or anyone, for that matter.
It's clear to me that vis is somefing Da Boyz can't deal wiv on their own – time for Da Gitz!
To say Gorduz has been a lucky git would be something of an understatement.
The larger wolves are bred by the Hobgoblins to pull their ramshackle chariots, and be mounts for their cruel Bosses and nasty Shamans.
If stabbin them in tha back aint enuff, then this poison will finish em off! Jab it in 'em!
Much has already been said about Gorduz' ability to stay alive, but let's not forget that he is also a formidable shooter, for a Hobgoblin, with a dead-eyed stare.
Like all Hobgoblins, only better, Gorduz is above all else, a cunning little git with lashings of low cunning and a beguiling level of stealth at his disposal.
Stick 'em wiv arrers'. Stick 'em with knives, 'an swords, and spears. Stick 'em quick and stick 'em where it 'urts. But most of all, stick 'em when they's looking the other way.
By virtue of his considerable experience, Gorduz is the stabbiest of all da stabberz. No question.
The Father of Darkness protects his children from sorcery through a variety of magical means, all of them twisted and obscure.
Having a thing for hats can be most useful when everyone keeps aiming at your head…
Death is always just a shot away.
Professional soldiery means never running out of ammo at the crucial moment.
A clever arrangement of lenses makes the target seem just that bit closer.
What use armour, or even magical defences, against such powerful ordnance?
What use armour, or even magical defences, against such powerful ordnance?
Looking absolutely hideous is a distinct advantage if you actually want others to be afraid of you.
Who knows whether it's down to a sense of duty or fear of summary execution if he fails, but this one will resolutely guard the Temple of Hashut to the bitter, bloody end.
The blackshard armour they wear protects the Infernal Castellan from much of the hurly-burly of battle, such as the worst effects of sizeable explosions.
The leaders of the Infernal Guard are clearly identifiable from their lavishly-decorated suits of armour …and the deafening roar of their voices when giving orders.
The Fire-Dwarfs' armouries are powered by a thousand immensely hot furnaces, from which all of their manufactured munitions are produced.
These are no ordinary bullets, for they have been forged in Hashut's roiling, molten fires, will go further and explode on contact.
Feel the fire, then live it.
As the hellforged bolts strike their target, their molten cores seep out, melting their defences and leaving them prone.
Some loudly state their view that killing from a distance, and other "sneaky" tactics, are unvalorous and unbefitting of a warrior, but they're wrong, for it is an art.
At the forefront of the battle, covered in blood and gods only know what else, shooting, slashing and stabbing the foe to a screaming death – *that's* where you'll find this one.
There are always improvements that can be made to any process; this one ensures the Chaos Dwarfs' war machines and artillery are calibrated to perfection.
Death is always just a shot away.
Professional soldiery means never running out of ammo at the crucial moment.
What use armour, or even magical defences, against such powerful ordnance?
There's something about them. Perhaps it is fear of punishment – death, even – that makes others do as this one says? Might that be it?
Having someone on hand who's extremely adept with the detail is most useful in war.
Access to Zharr-Naggrund's extensive armouries has its distinct benefits.
Enthralled though he is, his pact with a Sorcerer gives him strength...
You never get anywhere in life with a kind word. Now, a Bull Centaur-hide whip, on the other hand…
As creatures of flame and ash, the Red Bulls of Hashut cannot stray far from the Dark Lands, save for when the Winds of Magic – and Aqshy specifically – are at their strongest.
Believed to be a rare mutation of the Great Taurus, the magical Lammasu are the living embodiment of the Dark Land's rage, exhaling sorcerous clouds to protect their riders.
A more than capable overseer can work wonders in next to no time at all.
If the rewards promised are so great, even a Dwarf will debase himself in servitude to another master.
When the alternative is a brutal thrashing with an iron lash, troops tend to do exactly as they are told.
When you've scouted an advantageous position from which to pepper the enemy with missile fire, dig in, rain death, and repeat until done.
With so little rattle and recoil, a firearm can be kept stable enough to fire with greater accuracy from much further away.
Engineering ingenuity extended to mining and excavation implements can also prove useful to a battlefield skirmisher.
A modicum of care is just common sense when getting it wrong can find you trapped in another, infinitely worse dimension…

The priests of Hashut make the most horrifying offerings to their grim, malignant deity.
