Though the price may well be terrible, and it surely is, the Dawi-Zharr's lust for power remains insatiable and unquenchable.
When Father speaks of omens ill, his evil children listen intently to his heinous plans.
With a leader this cruel, is it any surprise that his troops are obedient and loyal to the end? Fear is the most effective motivator.
Hidden skill to grant Zhatan characters extra scaling
The Black's crimes are without number and his villainy without end, for Zhatan is savagery personified.
Subtlety is not a word in Zhatan's personal lexicon as he hacks and cleaves the foe asunder.
No matter the numbers, when counting the dead Zhatan's arithmetic always works in his favour.
So steeped in blood are they that the bloodstains on his hands can never be washed away.
It's not a race …or maybe it is? Zhatan's impatient armies rush right in, aching for slaughter.
In their mastery of war, the warhost of  Zharr feels nigh on invulnerable.
He exalts in the thick of battle, his joyous laughter draining the very blood from his enemies.
In the harsh, cruel world of the Dawi-Zharr, throwing your weight around is definitely the way to get what you want.
As creatures of flame and ash, the Red Bulls of Hashut cannot stray far from the Dark Lands, save for when the Winds of Magic – and Aqshy specifically – are at their strongest.
Believed to be a rare mutation of the Great Taurus, the magical Lammasu are the living embodiment of the Dark Land's rage, exhaling sorcerous clouds to protect their riders.
You'd be surprised how pliable they are when the alternative is certain, bloody death.
Dark deeds lead to ominous epithets…
The unquenchable thirst for blood is indiscriminate; prey and kin alike are fair game.
All the sons of Grungni can dig-in, enabling them to better resist physical attacks from the foe. Any missile attacks they can make are also improved.
Blood everywhere and fatal wounds. There's no walking away from this.

So entrenched in the dark sorcery of Hashut is he that more and more of this one's body parts have had to be substituted for mechanical replacements. In fact, he's probably more machine than Dwarf these days…
They care not for the cause, but the Renders this one controls would follow him into certain death if he commanded it.
Years spent standing next to artillery emplacements may have dulled his hearing, but this one's stentorian roar is louder than ever.
This one knows some Dwarfs that know other Dwarfs that kill some other Dwarfs. It's not what you know…
He moves unseen and unheard, so catching this Overseer off-guard is a tricky business.
This one has the approbation of the Hobgoblins… as if they ever really had a choice. The Fire-Dwarfs do not care either way!
Hear the summons of Hashut! The Dark Father calls you to slaughter, blood and fire exhorts you to war!
This one is in the unusual position of having the creatures under his command fear both his word and deed.
Without access to a steady supply of meat, getting Ogres to do what you want while staying out of the cook-pot is no easy feat.
Exchanging a hot, hard existence as a Daemonsmith for an easier life riding the convoys is very much a smart move, to the casual observer at least.
One shot, one kill. To be this good takes ages…
Building and driving the machines of war, in Chaos' Ruinous name.
In a society where the most heinous acts of cruelty are applauded – nay, *rewarded* – his atrocious tyranny is actually considered to be a positive thing.
Continually cheating death is an inspiring and not at all frustrating sight for the rabble of Hobgoblins in the Dawi-Zharr's service.
In the harsh, cruel world of the Dawi-Zharr, throwing your weight around is definitely the way to get what you want.
There are three ways of doing things around here: the right way, the wrong way, and the way that *I* do it. You understand?
Even by Chaos Dwarf standards, this one has a short fuse, and is quick to anger when something – anything – doesn't happen quickly enough.
This one won't move, won't roll over, won't give a solitary inch to anyone, ever, over anything.
You never quite know where you are with this one. He'd kill you dead just as soon as look at you.
This one only ever sees red, which is unfortunate for… well, for just about anyone who gets in his way!
Whereas, among the Chaos Dwarfs, compulsive urges are normally frowned upon, seeing a Daemonsmith chase down Labourers himself certainly is a sight.
If you want something done, threaten to kill everyone else until they do it.
Overly-enthusiastic describes this one well. He is blindly devoted to purging the weaker races of the Old World.
Exceeding sensibility when spellcasting, this Sorcerer has no concerns about the dangers of petrification.
Maybe it's the hat, maybe it's just his nature, but one thing is certain: this one is a devious, slippery character, even for a Chaos Dwarf!
This Daemonsmith is excessively proud of his own accomplishments, utterly convinced that he will soon rise to the very top of the ziggurat!
To say that this one is insensitive and cold-hearted would be a massive understatement, such is his unfeeling nature.
What's mine is mine. What's yours is mine too.
Unresolved past issues almost always lead to repercussions in the future. Oft-times, such things can be fatal…
Time spent at the Black Fortress does something to the already questionable character of a Chaos Dwarf…
He wouldn't let it lie. This one would, on the other hand, make it die. Watch out for him.
Maybe not today, maybe not tomorrow, but soon I shall unleash my fury upon you…
Having spent a considerable period banished from their own lands, this one had the time to reflect and improve on their many shortcomings.
Parsimonious to say the least, this one never wants to shell out on the best that money can buy.
Get in there, get bloody, get the job done – as soon as possible. Dallying's for losers.
I'm not saying this one's heading for a fall, but… well, yes, actually I am saying that.
Me, me, me, mine, mine, mine – that just about somes up this one's attitude to, well, everything, really.
Stoic and calm, this one is never anything less than totally in control.
It should be obvious that literally never being in a good mood is going to make one that little bit more brutal in melee.
Backhanders – hell, fronthanders, even, so unscrupulous is he.
Do we have to? Urgh, how tedious…
There are those who live for battle and risk death at every turn. Not so, this one, who is more than apprehensive when faced with the fray.
The lives of others mean nothing to this abject psycho, and neither does their property. If it's not nailed down, or even if it is, it's fair game to him.
Some would call them hasty, others dynamic and valiant, for this one acts on impulse, before the enemy have a chance to react.
There's pride, and then there's self-regarding, narcissistic vainglory. Not a good look.
Whatever you've got is what this one wants, and the more enchanted, the better.
Kill them all and keep the loot for yourself. It's not a negative quality to be acquisitive as, after all, it's a material world, no?
You'd think he was the only one ever to have achieved something, the way he goes on about every little victory.
No one likes him, but he really couldn't care less. He has an extremely thick skin, figuratively and literally, it seems.
Pride is supposed to come before a fall, but thus far, this one has not lived up to that proverb.
This one believes themselves to be better than others in every respect, and acts accordingly at every given opportunity.
This one's pent-up rage makes him an even more fiercesome adversary than he looks.
Forensic and well-versed in strategy and tactics, this one is truly a formidable opponent.
To say he is "up for a scrap" is a colossal understatement. In fact, you'd better bring your A-game if you find yourself facing this one on the battlefield.
Spite is every bit as spikey as a great big mace covered in spikes, in the right – or rather wrong – hands.
This one commands fire the way others wield swords. He's mad, bad and supremely dangerous to know – even for his own side!
You can't trust this one any further than you can throw him, and believe me, you'd struggle to even pick him up, so slippery is he…
His throat itches for the sweet taste of enchantment; the golden nectar that is true power.
His desire for magical power has become an obsession, to the point where he seeks out magic items to exclusion of all else.
Order, with all of its purity and sickening… goodness, is anathema to this one, and he hates it with a burning passion.
Destruction, and Death, its inseparable counterpart, are beyond odious and wicked in this one's eyes, and he will never change his mind on the matter.
Even for a race known for their inability to forget grudges, this one is utterly consumed by every slight, no matter how small, and will always pursue them to the bitter, bloody end.
More than utterly devoid of fear, this one sneers and scoffs at the foe, no matter how big and how hard they are.
Some go without question, some require "persuasion" and others brutal coercion, but in the end they will all go to serve Hashut one way or another.
I am no servant! I am a boyar's daughter. I have commanded a hundred Kossars! I can trace my lineage back one thousand years!
Ulrika's teen years were spent honing her duelling skills, which has left her with attack and defence capabilities of equal parity.
Always an advocate of getting stuck in, woe betide any who threaten or harm those dear to Ulrika Magdova.
As much as the best form of defence is offence, it remains essential to know how to defend oneself, for some adversaries may be stronger or faster than they first appear to be.
Even the most skilled professional soldier recognises the advantages of wearing a well-forged plate or suit of mail.
A highly-skilled horsewoman, Ulrika was trained in the equestrian arts from a very young age, and taught to fight just as effectively from the saddle as out of it.
In the real world, duelling is not simply a matter of striking and parrying. You must not just score a hit, you must kill your opponent, and do so before they kill you!
If you dish it out, it's literally vital that you can also take a degree of punishment before death's icy hand reaches out to claim your life.
Among Ulrika's many impressive martial abilities is her command of her compound bow, with which she demonstrates the skill to kill from a considerable distance away.
Always take an extra quiver or two on campaign, because you never know when you're going to need them.
Those filthy, craven ratmen hold no fear for Ulrika. In fact, she is a plague on their kind, wiping their stain from the land at every given opportunity.
Alongside Gotrek, the fabled Dwarf Slayer, and Felix, his mannish chronicler, Ulrika put down the Dragon Skjalandir after first blinding the behemoth and rendering it incapable.
What could and would surely kill another, Ulrika has survived, albeit with a little help from a magic-using friend…
Seeing her father slain by the Vampire Krieger gave Ulrika the strength, both physical and of will, to break free of her bonds, along with a passionate hatred.
Such a transformation fills the foe with terror while enabling Ulrika and her host to heal more easily.
Now she is fully reborn in blasphemy and blood, Ulrika can now control her hunger, increasing her power whilst draining that of her enemies.
My blood! The blood of my father! The blood of my country! To them I owe loyalty! To them I owe obedience!
Without a shield to protect her, it is vital that Ulrika remains swift of heel, so she can move, twist and dodge as the arrows rain down.
A useful benefit of the Blood Kiss is the ability to command the Lore of Shadow, which gives Ulrika greater protection against proponents of the other Winds of Magic.
The finest horses in the Old World, bred for their endurance and fiery temperament, barded for further protection.
Send messengers to the front! The right-flank must fight to the last man!
Lead with the heart, command with the mind.
Raise the signal banners! The left flank must stand strong!
Rare and majestic, Jade Longma only allow themselves to be ridden by the truly worthy.
A general's horse can be their most trusted and daring companion. Just don't name him 'Daisy'.
I am no Dragon, no mighty being descended to guide you! But I am their will! I am their Hand! And so too will you be!
Be as the bite of the Dragon!
…and I shall be all these things, and more!
Those who stand shoulder to shoulder with the sky will never fall to the earth.
In the eyes of the Emperor, the defence of Grand Cathay is a duty as sacred as the stone that represents it.
Inspiring others through displays of true grit and stalwart determination, the Gate Master never relents, even when the odds are very much stacked against him.
One truly adept in defensive tactics knows how best to evade such moves when made against them, and then how to deal their own killing blow.
Though the balloon remains fragile, a well-reinforced gondola can take prodigious numbers of arrows and gunfire in service of its pilots.
Your role is quite simple, really. When the assassin strikes, you jump in and beat them senseless.
Bring us closer! I must confirm the situation with my own eyes.
Through careful interpretation and vicious introspection, one can subtly shift their purpose as the flow of battle demands.
By carving deliberate grooves in the bullets, a piercing wail can be created as they pass through the air, disorienting the target.
Once you weed out the sycophants and bootlickers, you'll find no faster friends.
Those who work the land all their life build up a kinship with the boggy fields and deep forests.
Why use a sledgehammer to drive a nail?
Running out of food, bullets or arrows is as sure a killer as any blade.
In which you tell your men not just why they fight, but *how*.
Your tactics are a shameful display!
Have the books removed, I have studied enough!
When you can step with ease between mountaintops, what need have you of wings?
It's the quiet ones you need to watch… and ne'er a truer word said!
Ever-silent, always watching, watching... Saytang is always ready to smite the foes of the Dragon Emperor from the map in defence of his people.
In spite of appearances, Saytang never sleeps, and is always alert to the dangers from without that come to destroy Cathay's precious Harmony.
Saytang fires volley after volley of arrows into the enemy lines, weakening their ability to defend against the stone giant when he reaches their ranks.
What is that up in the sky? It is death, plain and simple; death for Cathay's mortal enemies, and an inspiration to its loyal warriors.
This enchanted stone statue is imbued with arcane abilities, as are others of its kind.
The giant, stone Construct known as Saytang can simply leap from peak to peak, far above the abundant valleys he is bound to defend.
Saytang does not need a quiver, for he has the Winds of Magic from which to draw, with all their eldritch power.
The eyes of the hawk, able to pluck a falling hair with a deft arrow sent from its bow.
Forces close to Saytang in battle almost become an extension of his own colossal stone limbs, always ready to swarm and strike at the wave of his mighty hand.
One of the myriad advantages of Constructs is their ability to see the threat coming from leagues away, enabling an effective defence to be mounted in relatively short order.
Magical ammunition isn't subject to quite the same restrictions as its solid equivalent, except when the Winds blow weaker across the field of battle.
This paragon of Cathayan Constructs imbues others of his kind with greater resilience, be they jade, jet, stone or flesh.
By whichever sneaky, underhanded means the foe chooses to enter Cathay, they will find Saytang and his friends waiting for them, and absolutely ready to do battle.
Advanced archery techniques such as this may trick the foe into making a fatal error, one which will turn them into screaming, fleshy pincushions as a result!
Only modders will read this, and I'd like you all to know tha-
Order is what separates us from the dark hordes of Chaos.
Stability is what lets us do as this great work demands.
And so I shall create that stability with every movement of pen and blade.
The Jade Regiments do not serve the Jade Court directly, despite their name, but administrating Cathay's political and economical centre makes such matters irrelevant.
Perhaps the most eclectic of the Cathayan warhosts. Serving Directly under Yuan Bo, the Celestial Court commands Cathay's Wizards and their magical craft in war.
The Celestial Court controls the Wizards of Cathay… and one never plays their best cards too soon, or for the benefit of others.
The mere presence of the Jade Dragon ensures that paperwork flows like water, and Yuan Bo is the shark beneath the waves.
The Dragons are adept at appearing human, but none more so than Yuan Bo, who cultivates a guise that does not betray the inhuman mind behind the unflinching eyes.
Little failures compound, and thus by aligning all things small and large with your purpose, you can banish all opposition.
When the drums of war are sounded, entire regiments of Astromancers are prepared to meet the demands of the empire.
When he discards the false image of humanity, Yuan Bo is a terrifying spectre of an age from before the thinking races of the world.
Ever vigilant, always watching; from the highest peaks in Cathay, Saytang's arrows whistle on the wind, foreshadowing the deaths of those who threaten the Silk Lands.
Executor and Executioner, Yuan Bo wears many hats, his twin stewardship of the Jade and Celestial Courts granting him authority only matched by the Emperor and Empress themselves.
Consecrated by the Cult of Ursun to be the Tzarina's noble guardian, the Golden Knight walks the near-invisible line between church and state.
Place your feet well, step not on the branch and rustle not the bush, lest the Hag Mother come and takes you away forever…
What is truly left when you have forgotten your original form completely?
This one's loyalty is to the crown of Kislev and its current wearer, without question, and to the bitter end, if such sacrifice is necessary.
The sacred beasts of Kislev must only be killed by the strength of one's hand or the flight of an arrow.
A life lived hand-in-hand with nature means that, when this one calls upon the trees, they answer his request.
The enemies of Kislev shall never see Ursun's men coming until it is far, far too late.
His knowledge of the forest and its inhabitants give this one a better understanding than most of how they can be fielded in its defence.
He knows the lands, its rivers, its streams; the best spots to defend, the best places to strike.
Never forget where you come from, especially if you wish the peasants to fight for you when war comes to Kislev.
The God of Nature is fiercely protective of his domain. Only the foolish provoke his wrath.
The Golden Knight may be the champion of Tzarina Katarin, but she is also sworn to defend all Kislev from those who dare invade its hallowed borders.
It's not just warriors bearing steel that Naryska will best – spellcasters and Daemons also find their weapons blunted against her golden carapace, and that of the Lord under her protection.
Unusually, Naryska fights with the blessings of both the Great Orthodoxy and the Ice Court, uniting two ancient institutions, so often at odds, in a single, glorious purpose.
Whomsoever is leading Kislev's armies on the day of battle, be it the Tzarina herself or one of her loyal generals, the Golden Knight will guard them with her life.
No Kislevite warrior trains longer or harder than Naryska Leysa, for even the best among them cannot match her levels of determination and sheer stubborn pride.
Taller than many men, armed and armoured to the teeth and beyond – the Golden Knight is a beacon of courage on the battlefield; an example to all Kislevites and the bane of their foes.
When Naryska Leysa's noble father died in battle at Boris Ursus' side, there was only one real choice to be his replacement and become the new Golden Knight.
Though many have tried, none have yet broken through Naryska's steely resolve or bested her in single combat, such is her martial skill.
Naryska is the daughter of the previous Golden Knight, whose valorous blood clearly flows through her veins and guides her noble actions against the Motherland's foes.
The Golden Knight impresses potential allies just as much as she inspires its rank-and-file troops, making them more willing to join with Kislev for their mutual advantage and gain.
She does not fight for Tzarina Katarin alone, but the Motherland as a whole, for if it fell to invaders from without, the Golden Knight would have no further purpose in life.
You don't become the Golden Knight if you aren't the most true-hearted warrior in the land, who would die a thousand times to save Kislev from its most-hated enemies.
When Katarin goes to war, all Kislev mobilises to ensure her victory, and her greatest living warrior is always first amongst them.
Although she has no equals among the Ice Guard, their fighting prowess improves when in Naryska's presence, as the warrior-women seek to impress her with their own bravery and martial skill.
Those who fight alongside the Golden Knight inevitably find that the extensive experience she has gained in battle, fighting Kislev's enemies to a bloody death, rubs off on them too.
The men and women who have fought with the Golden Knight and proved their mettle are rewarded with fine ceremonial armour plates as a mark of their achievements.
Every member of the armies with whom the Golden Knight serves becomes that little bit tougher and more resilient, as bonds of blood and honour are formed through shared experience.
To bring fear and panic to a battlefield, few other than the Ice Court’s most accomplished can wrangle a deadly ice drake into their service.
The Ice Court’s reinforced sled is drawn by mighty steeds with breath like the winter wind, and whose flanks shimmer with glittering ice crystals.
Not all who wander are lost.
The natural state of the world is that of untouched wilderness, free from the meddling of all outsiders.
From between the branches they came…
The Hags of the wood find kinship among their own comes easily; they are all bound by the same thread, after all.
Malediction upon malediction, the curse weighs heavily on those who dare trespass.
Directing covens of Hags to do the work of the wild allows Ostankya to weave greater rituals befitting of her station.
The citizenry of rural Kislev have a begrudging-yet-thankful relationship with the Hags, wherein proper respect begets a startling lack of misfortune.
Never attack a witch close to the heart of her power.
Ostankya speaks no complicated truths, no poetic musings. She simply lays bare the natural world and brings a surety of purpose to her followers.
You'd better start believing in fairy tales, 'cos you're in one!
A slightest pinch of hate to make the curse just that much harder to bear.
Bear them close to your heart, for the wild holds sole domain over you now.
Drop these seeds into your garden and your harvest shall be bountiful indeed! But pick not the eye-laden stalk, not even once!
Into the boughs and under the snow, where the witches dance and the new spring grows.
A root to bind arrows to the earth and a simple switch of wood from a young sprout to return their magics to the spring from which it came.
Rise now, twisted branch and mossy stone!
The rasp of wood, freely given, upon snow heralds their approach...
Familiars of the wood bound and leap between the shadows, ready to strike out if the deal is deemed sour.
Of all the twisting of the Winds, curses come most naturally to the Hags.
A leader is best appointed with a wise advisor by their side… One that knows the proper ways of the world.
When muscles reknit and bones mend, there is little need to consider ones own safety.
The life overflows from within, impossible to quell or stem, the only recourse is rampant action.
Wherever he steps, life sprouts, the branches straining under bushels of overripe fruit, flowers so bright they sear the eyes.
…and life goes on and on and on and on and on and on and on and on and on and on and on and on and on...
Aekold wields the Windblade, a greatsword that can fly through the air to scythe down the foe, or empower Aekold himself to strike with the swiftness of the wind!
Aekold's new knightly brotherhood has proven far more appreciative of his talents.
Once a knight of the Empire, Aekold desires nothing more than to return to those who betrayed him and show them the truth of the world…
In their eternal search, the Scribes have picked up a couple knacks for wringing extra Winds from this place.
If they've seen it before, they have absolutely no need to see it again.
The first spells the Scribes collected were those of the Daemons from which they stemmed.
These scrolls glow with the ominous light of Warpstone, and the faint chittering of vermin can be heard.
These scrolls scream, literally, when unfurled, eternally hungry for meat and war.
When these scrolls are unfurled near places of death, remains have a habit of bursting into spontaneous, short-lived life.
These scrolls each come in pairs, each one only complete when held alongside its twin, unfortunately making them very annoying to store.
These scrolls have a certain haughty air around them, Xirat'p finds them insufferably judgemental.
Each home to a minor Daemon bound in the parchment, these scrolls jump into Xirat'p's hands as if eager to unleash their destruction on the material world.
Sometimes the Scribes retrieve these scrolls to bask in the refreshing winter chill on a hot summer's day.
Larger than any other scrolls, these bear the weighty incantations that would consume a mortal Wizard.
These scrolls smoulder slightly, consumed by an ever-burning flame.
These scrolls gently scintillate like stars in the night sky.
These scrolls are not truly scrolls at all, but blades folded into their shape! Watch those fingers!
Each time these scrolls are unfurled, small insects burst forth all over the nearby area.
These scrolls must be trimmed regularly, lest the they become subsumed by the various branches and leaves sprouting from within.
Of their vast collection, these scrolls are among their least favourite, as merely unfurling them threatens to banish the Scribes back to the Realm of Chaos!
These scrolls must regularly be scribed again, as the Winds of Shyish eat away at their form, much to the Scribes dismay.
It is only the providence of the Architect of Fate himself that even allows these scrolls to be retrieved when necessary, as they can only be taken from between the shadows of other scrolls.
What once was one, now is two.\\n\\nAnd together we will blast you!
Even the Scribes have favourites among the scrolls.
We can enscribe it if we try!
The cackling never ends, and you'll know not if it's two or a thousand maniacal voices raised in mockery!
The Blue Scribes are fragments of the great changer himself, forever bound to wander the world searching for every spell – past, present and future.
While not exactly masterful agents of great cunning or skill, a boundless supply of esoteric magic makes up for many shortcomings.
Xirat'P and P'tarix are not fleeting constructs driven to find entertainment or combust. No, they are surly and cunning combatants with years of experience.
The moments that evoke the highest emotions are those that occur when the mask slips and falls.
The disguise can be as exact as needed. Sometimes that need includes a striking set of tentacles!
Logistics, training and all those other nonsensical concepts don't apply when you can simply appear fully-formed with bow in hand.
You know, I'm something of a Wizard myself...
And when the curtain falls, the victim is left stupefied as the Changeling pulls back to savour his spoils.
Take from each guise a little sliver of what makes them special, and bring it to the fore.
Would you really strike an old friend?
I put on my robe and Wizard guise…
Where's my staff!? Bring me my armour! No, that suit has no shoes! WHO'S RESPONSIBLE?
You always make time for the shape of a friend.
Those who follow the Changeling find themselves particularly mutable. One moment they are themselves, the next they are another. When enough have passed, they can never find themselves again.
They truly are mad, but you wouldn't know until it is way, way too late.
What do you mean I already had the supplies sent to the front?
Do not question providence. The grinning quartermaster and the gentle Wizard have always worked here.
...and that's why you should loan me your best regiments. Your personal guard, perhaps?
Halt, who goes there!? The patrol has already passed through! Identify yourselves!
You probably expected me to say "Now you don't", but it was merely a cunning ruse…
Even the greatest of Daemons have been defeated on their travels, and oft-times by one such as this.
Some people don't need friends; in fact, friends might get in the way and be accidentally killed in a particularly nasty way.
Distinguished by his scars he may be, but since the point of being a Slayer is to die, one wonders when this one is going to start applying himself to the task at hand.
If you're gonna die, die with yer boots on! -- Ancient Slayer proverb
Many a tale, many a promise, and many a grave threat is scored into these fleshy drapes, detailing a life spent in the dogged pursuit of death…  and chiefly, their own!
The deeds of this one's life are told through the many scars that adorn his timeworn and battle-aged skin.
When led by a Dwarf of sufficient calibre, a band of Slayers is many times more lethal – speeding to the heart of the action to cut it from the foe's still-screaming body!
Those who seek only a glorious death have little, or less, at least, use for money, because, after all, you can't take it with you.
When you're this good with a bow, you don't necessarily need to endanger your immortal soul to kill your enemies.
Dragons? Smagons. Where is it? Come here, you, it's time to die!
There's knowing no fear and then there's never having heard the word, let alone the concept. That's how mad you have to be go up against Ruin and win.
This one'll take on all-comers, no matter how large and hostile they may be. The way he sees it, if he dies trying, mores the better.
Of course, the work never ends, and neither should it, for the slaughter is ceaseless. They say that work is its own reward, after all.
Once a Plaguebearer, always a Plaguebearer. You can't fight nature.
Epidemius has brought a foetid seedling from the Garden of Blight to be cultivated in the mortal world.
Daemons are even more resistant to objects in the mortal realm than in their own dark dimensions.
The Tallyman has ascended further still, at last becoming the right-hand man of the Urfather Himself.
The Tallyman's Blades are tied to the world, and therefore able to last for days on end in the mortal realm.

When the Rot Reports have been collected and counted, the efficency of each and every disease can be collated, calculated, correlated, cross-referenced and catalogued. The malady itself can then be… circulated.
Nothing is more powerful than pure, ruthless aggression.
The rot beasts thrash and bray violently with every step – remaining steady requires more than simply holding on for dear life.
Mediocrity does nothing for the Fly Lord's cause; if sickness is to spread far and wide, elite training is a necessity.
As the Rot Beasts' claws tear into the earth at speed, and hooves pound through mud and grime, every enemy of Nurgle recoils in fear.
Rushing forth in the name of utter Ruin, Kayzk is surrounded by only the best riders in all the realms.
A huge and powerful figure, Kayzk dwarfs his enemies, unmoving in the face of their every attack.
Line up the largest, most ungainly and lumbering oafs among any enemy, and Kayzk will knock them down one by one.
No retreat, no surrender. Keep cutting them down until no more rise to face you.
Sometimes mere proximity, as opposed to direct contact, is enough for Nurgle's many foul diseases to spread – so virulent are his infections and plagues.
Possessed as he is of a body long devoid of feeling, Kayzk is extremely difficult to bring down, let alone kill outright.
The Maggot Lord is so contagious that he has only to slither past someone to infect them with his foul pestilence.
Tamurkhan is much more than the giant corpse maggot whose form he took; he is now a being of untold power, thanks to his dear Grandfather's love and care.
The Maggot  is especially tough and durable, even for one of his kind, and can survive just about anything the various worlds can throw at him.
After killing and inhabiting the body of a great Ogre Tyrant, the followers of the Maw have fallen to Tamurkhan's corruption.
Bubebolos stands above others as the largest of his kind. With Tamurkhan upon his back, all other Toad Dragons fall into line.
As Tamurkhan leads a devastating army of corrupted mortals and Daemons, like-minded forces attracted by his Ruin converge to form his grand warhost.
Tamurkhan and his army don't get tired, and they never, ever give up.
Heeding rumours that the Favoured of Nurgle is one of the fabled four Sons of the Great Kurgan, mortal followers of Chaos bow to his command.
Working with gunpowder takes a lot of patience – one wrong move and you might lose your trigger finger... or worse!
A hail of bullets tends to put the enemy off their stroke.
Arrows, cannonballs and more esoteric munitions – you can never have too many when the war never ends.
Ofttimes, events dictate a jury-rigged repair while the battle rages around you.
The living personification of courage, as the Fearless was many centuries before him.
When you've been fighting for decades, the accumulated scars start to act as a leathery carapace in their own right.
Right across the Old World I've walked, and the New, as well. There's no corner I've not visited, no horror I've not seen... and killed.
Do not worry, father, I will fight for the both of us. And if the time is right, I will gladly die for the both of us as well.

I am a Dwarf! My honour is my life and without it I am nothing. I shall become a Slayer. I shall seek redemption in the eyes of my Ancestors. I shall become as death to my enemies, until I face he that takes my life and my shame.
Behind all the hot-headed bravado and suicidal bravery stands a Dwarf who takes the leadership of his Slayer band very, VERY seriously.
Garagrim is not as hot-headed or as pig-blind as he likes to appear; he plays the role of Slayer to the best of his ability, but can think when required to.
Many blows over many battles have hardened this warrior beyond compare, making his hide as tough as Dragon scales.
As War-mourner, it's Garagrim's duty to tend to the Shrine of Grimnir, allowing him to open up the temple's store of ancient rune axes left in tribute.
With three crests of angry orange hair, an extremely hard stare, and a visible, bubbling resentment coupled with a severe lack of social graces, Garagrim is very much the Slayer's Slayer.
In a society such as the Dwarfs', built upon centuries of tradition and respect for the past, who your Ancestors are really does matter.
There's nothing like bitter personal experience to ensure that leadership qualities come to the fore. Today, the warband; tomorrow, the Hold.
By virtue of his elevated status, this one has contacts within the Dwarf leadership that enable information and power to flow in both directions more easily.
There's little time for carousing, or even sitting about, when there's a multitude of heinous grievances to be addressed!
In fact, that's all there is to it: keep doing that until the red – or green or blue or black – water sprays all over the place like a fleshy geyser …like a fleshy geyser that won't stop screaming.
These armour plates have been girded with runes to ensure the wearer is protected from all manner of attacks.
Dawi of distinction tend to have the best weapons, whether made specially for them or taken as spoils from their defeated foes.
This Lord's ability to withstand prolonged combat and show fortitude has a positive effect on those fighting nearby.
All Dwarfs are taught to kill face-to-face just as soon as they can fight, but learning to kill from a distance requires an altogether different skillset.
Always bring more arrows than you think you'll need. If nothing else, it's fun to make pincushions out of their corpses.
Never let them get too close and pin yer down, 'cos that's when having shorter legs starts to become a disadvantage. The only time, in fact.
No matter how fine a shot you think you are, you can always be better.
It truly is amazing how something so small can wreak so much explosive devastation.

Although it was his early disasters that saw Malakai thrown out of the Engineers' Guild, he has continued to invent machines useful to Gotrek and his allies, with a far greater degree of success – fortunately!
It was his inventing prowess, or initial lack thereof, that forced Malakai to seek redemption through a glorious death in battle – something he pursues with the utmost seriousness!
Few machines are irreparable by Malakai’s reckoning, for a true engineer never ceases to learn from their tinkering.
Nobody can optimise a heavy gun or mortar the way Malakai can; when the Dawi rain fire down upon their enemies, his upgrades ensure there are no survivors.
Through Malakai's genius, what once was mere design is brought to life in contraptions of hulking metal and endless firepower.
A little tweak here, a little adjustment there and… Boom! Hundreds of dead Goblins, as they should be.
When the Dawi are in need, exhaustion is an act of cowardice – there is simply no time for rest.
With age and experience comes an enduring grit that allows veterans to stand undaunted in the face of any foe.
I don’t need much in this life but the armour on my chest and the weapon in my hand.
None can match the rage of one brimming with the fury of a thousand battles, cutting through foes in a frenzy of death.
There's one thing you should know about me: I go wherever I damn well please!
With the power of Runic Magic at your side, there's little in this world or any other that can do to bring you low.
Think of it as a belt *and* braces – protection on top of protection, in case they come at your with their foul magicks.
Proving their innate superiority, and with it that of the Dwarf race, runes can be used to hamper the Winds of Magic and therefore their benefit to the enemy.
It takes a very long time to get to know a Runelord, and longer still to know which secrets he even holds, let alone their true nature and meaning.
Seperate runes struck in the right order can call upon the different Ancestor Gods. Call upon Grimnir to unlock a furious energy.
Seperate runes struck in the right order can call upon the different Ancestor Gods. Call upon Grungni to improve the power of weapons and armour.
Seperate runes struck in the right order can call upon the different Ancestor Gods. Call upon Valaya for assurance of loyalty in crucial moments.
Centuries of innovative, careful craft and legendary martial skill can be brought to bear on present-day battlefields, that the foe might be smited from existence.
As a Slayer pursues his quarry, the Runesmith's thirst for knowledge is every bit as relentless, because only through understanding will we wipe the foe from the mountains once and for all.
There are some things that simply cannot be taught. You either know them or you don't; it's as simple as that.
The more runes you craft, the stronger and more powerful they – and you – will become; practice makes perfect, after all.
The cumulative teachings of the Ancestors, directed through time to rupture the bodies of those who dare challenge Dawi supremacy.
Long has the High King yearned to avenge the wrongs done to his people by striking clean the entire ledger of the Great Book of Grudges!
Hills, forest, desert – you name it, those clever boys from the Empire have got it covered.
Those who bear the Mark of Hysh are practitioners of the magical Lore of Light, and the bane of Chaos, for they are able to control and manipulate the White Wind of Magic.
All manner of useful magical artefacts have been stored by Elspeth over the many, many years she has wound her way through this troubled world.
This enchanted root from Athel Loren gifts the power of healing to whomsoever is holding it.
She who has the ear of the Countess Emmanuelle von Liebwitz is a powerful person indeed…
Although a member of the hallowed Amethyst Order of Wizards, Elspeth is very much an outlier among her peers for her fierce independence and extensive knowledge of Shyish.
Parents warn their children about straying into the Gardens of Morr at nightfall, for that is where Elspeth's blackened tower stands, and her ethereal power is said to manifest.
No one knows quite how long Elspeth has lived, or even if she lives at all anymore, but her name has been spoken of in hushed tones by at least three generations of Nulners.
Elspeth von Draken comes from an illustrious bloodline of magic-users blessed with increased sensitivity to the Winds of Magic.
With its powerful clockwork mechanism, this bucking equine contraption can demolish most things that suffer the impact of being in its rider’s path.
Tell me dying one… are you afraid? I can assure you, you should be.
A master of the flame learns to channel their anger towards their enemies while shielding their allies from harm.
A Celestial Wizard is a welcome addition to any army, for their mastery of the stars allows them to predict where trouble might strike.
The Jade Order teaches of nature's power, and how to tap into its endless reserves of endurance.
Where darkness and corruption seep across the land, light must shine the brightest, purifying every shadow.
Some Wizards sink into darkness like a shroud, enveloping themselves in shadow to better stalk their foes.
After myriad hours of study, poring over arcane manuals and ancient, dusty tomes, mastery of spells now comes naturally.
Knowledge of ancient wisdoms often places Wizards into positions of great importance, enabling them to make connections across the Empire and foreign lands too.
This Wizard has undoubtedly studied for many years to hone their craft, but there's always more to learn.
Far from the frail and willowy image of decrepit old men secreted away in crumbling towers, Battle Wizards must be exemplars of well-honed athleticism and strength.
As a graduate of the Imperial Colleges, this one is well versed in man-to-man combat. The principle has to be the same for man-to-Daemon, right?
This hardened warrior has learnt to not only protect themselves, but those around them also.
This one has seen his fair share of combat – more, even, which means he knows exactly how and when to deliver the deathblow.
This one is often found leading a mounted charge from the front, with trusted subordinates left behind in their wake!
A man of the people, this one fights on the frontline among his men, increasing their eagerness for the battle.
Root out and destroy Greenskins, the servants of Chaos, and those who use corrupt magic, wherever they may hide.
Move in the shadows to serve the light.
When tracking one's prey, best stick to the light of the moon.
Never back down, and never step out of line, for every Imperial order is law.
The Imperial Witch Hunters have attended many funerals… mostly for their own victims.
Their only saviour shall be the stake…
Don't be stingy with your bullets if you're not sure they're really *dead* dead.
Extra layers of flame retardant material are a sensible precaution for a volatile job.
Stand back and hit 'em from afar… The fools will never see it coming!
Stand back and hit 'em from afar… The fools will never see it coming!
Innovation is the first step to success; the rest requires surviving test-cases.
By wooden frame and solid stone, and more than a modicum of skills, towering structures shall rise up out of the earth.
The groaning of metal and booming of artillery is distracting to say the least, but to some it sounds like... home.
The groaning of metal and booming of artillery is distracting to say the least, but to some it sounds like... home.
Those walls are solid and sturdy, to be sure. I'll bring 'em down all the same.
A veteran of countless battles, this one has a hunger for slaughter and a thirst for blood.
One doesn't reach the rank of General without having survived many a battle.
This one's many courageous deeds are celebrated far and wide across the Empire, with many speaking of their might and determination in the very thick of battle.
The blades of the Empire slice through the enemy like so many knives through so much fleshy butter.
Courage, duty, honour – all meaningless without discipline. This commander demands their troops be perfectly drilled, that they may stand fast against even the darkest of the Empire's foes.
With their general at its head, the Empire's cavalry charge into battle with great zeal.
Having friends in the high places of Imperial society has its benefits. It's always *who* you know...
This one is loved and respected by their troops, many of whom have come from all over the world to fight at their side.
An Engineer can create machines powerful enough to counter anything the foe can throw at them. Well, that's the theory anyway…
The Empire's Engineers know how best to calibrate their weapons for increased range.
If it can be shot at the foe, this one knows everything apposite about its design and use.
Although always a force to be reckoned with, this generally quiet, unassuming man of learning can turn on the head of a coin into an expert killer.
Granted command of a Steam Tank, even an Engineer can dominate a battlefield, expertly striking the delicate balance of directing pressured steam between wheel-pistons and steam-belching weapons.
Working with gunpowder takes alot of patience... one wrong move and you might lose your trigger finger... or more!
There is never a spare moment for a Master Engineer – any free time is spent buried in schematics diagrams in order to perfect their designs.
A true master knows there is more than one way to defeat your enemies. Being thrown off your feat by a nearby blast is enough to leave many disorientated, deaf and defenceless.
A Master Engineer's garments must be extremely resistant to both fire and ballistics, because if a failed experiment doesn't get them, the apparatus that comes flying at them afterwards surely will!
An Engineer doesn't just make machines of war. Months of design and innovation have paid off, and now your navigators reap the benefit.
The machines of the Empire aren't immune to failure, but luckily with a Master Engineer nearby, they rarely stay broken for long.
What better way to increase your firepower than with.. fire?! These firebombs will set ablaze all who survive the initial blast.
Bruckner's chosen mount both strikes fear and instils confidence, as the mighty Demigryph bounds across the battlefield at its master's behest.
The Countess' Hound of Judgement is her Judicial Champion when the ancient rite of trial-by-combat is invoked within the Imperial aristocracy.
Whether it's his hulking frame, or the many stories of his past deeds, but few can stand in this one's presence without feeling a little awestruck.
Bruckner doesn't really need a sword because his body is a weapon in its own right.
As Nuln's official headsman and Countess Emmanuelle's personal champion, Theodore Bruckner is known colloquially as the Hound of Judgement, such is his tenacity to see bloody justice done.
Where he comes from, nobody knows…
A general's horse can be their most trusted and daring companion. Just don't name him 'Daisy'.
An Imperial pegasus is a noble, winged steed, intelligent and loyal.
This hardened warrior has learnt to not only protect themselves, but those around them also.
As possibly the most blessed of all Grandfather's favoured, Kayzk long ago lost all form and feeling, which has given him a certain physical resilience.
This Dawi follows all the tenets of the Engineers' Guild to the very letter, such is his dedication to his craft.
This one's hands are always busy working on this contraption or that; his fellow Dawi put up with it because the results of his tinkering simply cannot be argued with.
Fortunately, this Dawi is just as dedicated to the advancement of his people as he is to drinking his own body weight, and yours, in Bugman's Best every night.
As a Dawi elder statesman, who has lived long and seen much, this one is one of the most respected figures in his Hold.
Stout and sturdy, as every good Dawi should be.
This Dawi who has dedicated his life to ticking off as many entries from the Book of Grudges as is Dwarfly possible.
This enterprising Dawi has spent some time with his local band of Rangers and has learned many of their skills for himself.
The more moneyed Dawi Clans are able to pay for extra protection when marching between Holds or on campaign with a Throng.
This Dawi master of the runes can trace his lineage back to Thungni, God of Runic Magic and Runesmithing.
A rather unusual trait for a Dawi, but this one make great use of his natural sprightly dexterity when settling grudges.
It is always a great loss to a Hold when a veteran passes, but they may leave their masterwork az to a worthy successor or descendant, that their important work may continue.
Elspeth von Draken is a woman brimming with arcane power, whose past – and indeed present – is shrouded in ever-deeper layers of enticing mystery and menacing threat.
Theodore Bruckner is the embodiment of bloody-handed judgment and a prolific taker of heads, should the law require such a manner of restitution for crimes committed against the state.
Despite only ever really wanting a quiet life, Felix ended up swearing a blood-oath to Gotrek, becoming his companion on the Slayer's quest to find his own, personal glorious doom.
To many, a rooted contradiction, to some, salvation personified.
The chosen Tallyman of Nurgle is a sight to behold for all the Urfather's followers, his evergrowing paperwork illustrating the Fly Lord's power.
Myriad open sores weep with festering, foetid pus, enabling Neiglen's foul plagues to infect quickly and spread faster than before.
From which species this one comes is very much open to question, so distorted have their features become through Grandfather Nurgle's loving caresses.
What this one doesn't know about plagues, diseases, contagions, maladies, infections and epidemics simply isn't worth knowing.
This nasty little concoction came from no one knows quite whence to spread the vilest pestilence, horrific, weeping buboes, and a terrifying, screaming death to all across the land.
Arrows, cannonballs and more esoteric munitions – you can never have too many when the war never ends.
The dread carriages of the Ruinous hosts are more than just machines of war; they are symbols of status and power.
The dread steeds of Chaos are more than mere horses, but creatures tainted by Daemon blood, said to be gifts from the Dark Gods themselves.
The dread steeds of Chaos are more than mere horses, but creatures tainted by Daemon blood, said to be gifts from the Dark Gods themselves.
A vast, mobile altar allows the souls of the slain to be ritualistically condemned directly from the field of slaughter.
The dread steeds of Chaos are more than mere horses, but creatures tainted by Daemon blood, said to be gifts from the Dark Gods themselves.
A vast, mobile altar allows the souls of the slain to be ritualistically condemned directly from the field of slaughter.
[HIDDEN] Skill used to provide unique bonuses for the Nemesis Crown Lord in final battle of DLC25
[HIDDEN] Skill used to provide unique bonuses for the Monster Lord in DLC25
[HIDDEN] Skill used to provide unique bonuses for the Night Goblin Lord in DLC25
[HIDDEN] Skill used to provide unique bonuses for the Spider Lord in DLC25
Years of adventure and the many dangers faced along the way have made Felix fast on his feet and hard to pin down.
Despite almost drowning in the encounter, felling a mighty Flame-Drake taught Felix how to pierce even the mightiest of hides.
Seemingly endless drills – and more importantly, numerous battles – has accustomed Felix to deadly use of his Rune Sword Karaghul, which he wields with ever-burgeoning skill.
You've either got it or you haven't, and Felix is capable of dazzling anyone and everyone.
Remembering Kirsten's death at Manfred's hands stirs a lethal ferocity deep within Felix Jaeger.
Being as he is the companion of a Dwarf Slayer, Felix often finds himself having to adopt more diplomatic role, using his natural charisma to venture where he wishes without angering the locals.
His prior work as a doorman has given Felix a keen sense of when an unwanted guest has arrived.
Guided by either a sense of honour or duty from his oath, the Rememberer must be present until the last moment of his companion's murderous life.
Successfully dealing with plagues of degenerate Ratmen requires both nouse and experience.
Even the greatest of Daemons have been defeated on their travels, and oft-times by one such as this.
To the casual observer, usually while running away very fast, the Beastmen are a disorganised, inept rabble. Yet nothing could be further from the truth – they are both cunning and swift.
When you face an Orc, don't let their size intimidate you – simply take immediate advantage of their lack of speed and discipline.
When the pointy-ears fire their arrows, we will fight in the shade!
It's simple – when the head comes away from the neck, it's over. For good this time!
The best form of defence is rarely defence, in the eyes of a Slayer.
Never one to faff around, Gotrek moves swiftly across the battlefield to find foes worthy of his doom.
A pathetic, ignominious doom is not enough for the greatest Slayer yet to die.
Many blows over many battles have hardened this warrior beyond compare, making his hide as tough as Dragon scales.
Incensed that his noble death has not yet presented itself, Gotrek is determined to get to the enemy before anyone else.
Dwarfs are not fast, yet they will soldier on, always moving despite the hazards encountered.
All those within the Slayer Cult are doomed to follow Grimnir's fate; it is only a question of when, not if.
What is the greatest Slayer of them all to do when there's nothing left to kill?
An experienced adventurer, Gotrek has seen many lands and faced many foes. Now, even the mightiest of blows are nought but a scratch for the Slayer.
Gotrek no longer breaks a sweat in battle, so seasoned a warrior is he. This perceived lack of effort strikes fear into the foe's pathetic un-Dawi hearts.
Those strong enough to tame the powerful, unruly Razorgors can harness them for chariots.
Pugnacious and stubborn, the war beasts that pull these ramshackle chariots are grotesque combinations of great boar and mighty ram.
While forging armour for Beastmen would be impractical, they can be clad in thick bark stripped from the tallest of trees, which offers a reasonable level of protection.
The Bray Shaman is a master at goading his beasts into the most vicious action imaginable.
The mutants that cower in humanity's forests are drawn to Tamurkhan's banner, such is his reputation for strength.
Fearing being crushed by Tamurkhan, the Three-Horn spreads Nurglish corruption to appease the Urfather's favoured one.
The greater the number of Labourers, the more your coffers will swell.
The more you have available to spend, the greater the number of Labourers you can support.
With a seemingly never-ending supply train, this Infernal Castellan has all the firepower he needs at his stumpy, armoured fingertips.
Tamurkhan's march promises much wealth for the greedy, corrupt Dawi-Zharr; unsurprisingly, all at their capital are eager to profit.
With a weapon of sufficiently high calibre, a ready supply of ammunition, and no small amount of skill from the shooter, no target is too large to be brought down.
The very best warriors don't tire in battle, they just get angrier, and fight with even greater savagery.
Khargan is crazy for killing, yet killing makes Khargan crazy! It's the literal definition of a vicious circle…
Violence bordering on absolute delirium; 'berserk' doesn't even come close.
Some warriors just want to follow a madman into infamy, and do not care about the inevitable consequences that will follow.
With minacious magics galore, the Restorer can heal even gaping, sucking wounds beyond the limits of a Troll's natural regenerative capabilities.
When a flying magical cleaver just isn't enough...
Sometimes called the Restorer, the Ketzak Fimdirach is a male Fimir shaman of singular power, seen only once in a generation among his benighted species.
A friend of the Ketzak Fimdirach is a friend of all Fimir, and of fouler things which live in the caves and swamps, far from prying, human eyes.
For slaying the dread beast Skraelsbane, Mournhowl is feared and respected by the Northmen.
Though Mournhowl has sated his hunger for revenge on the beast that slew his family, the fires of retribution are not so easily doused once alight.
Though lupine in aspect, the Werekin Chieftain retains the heart of a man as he growls his mournful tale.
The terrifying, echoing howls of a cadre of Skin Wolves are enough to cripple any foe with fearful indecision.
Though once a man in aspect, the Werekin Chieftain has gained the cunning of a wolf – absolutely haring into the fray alongside monsters that can match his lupine ferocity.
These are no ordinary bullets, for they have been forged in Hashut's roiling, molten fires, going further and exploding on contact.
Kayzk the Befouled is so named because the Fly Lord has corrupted and distorted each and every aspect of his being in ways that no one can truly comprehend.
The Kurgan Champion's unquenchable fiery ardour for his Ruinous work is quite literally infectious…
Only the best weapons and armour are good enough for this strong and noble Dawi hero.
People have a habit of following the suicidally brave into danger, mistaking their madness for courage.
Never give up, never give in, never retreat, and never, ever surrender. Never give an inch; always move forward.
This one's reputation for great deeds in the service of all Dwarfkind ensures other Dawi always have a care for his wellbeing.
Bearing the arms and wearing the armour of his Ancestors make it quite clear that only a coward and a failure blames his tools.
There’s little you can do to get under the skin of one who has rubbed shoulders with the diseased for so long.
Best not touch, lest something – everything – comes off in your hand.
You cannot escape death indefinitely… Well, you can, but not without a College education, generally speaking. Most will eventually feel infirmity's firm cruel grip, one way or another.
The champion executioner of Ogrekind and a slayer of kings and heroes; he is Bragg the Gutsman and none he marks for slaughter ever survive.
A rising legend amongst the Forest Goblins, Snagla Grobspit is at the forefront of every Greenskin victory.
Bragg feels the need to kill calling him as surely as he feels the voracious stirring of the Great Maw in his own belly.
The difference between a battle and a bloodbath is how much meat there is to feast on afterwards.
Bragg does not fight with grace or finesse, for such traits elude all Ogres, but has a natural gift for landing blows with maximum damage.
Presented with his first blade as a whelp to swing about with wild abandon, Bragg has always shown a great affinity for decapitation.
Where Bragg walks, he goes alone – such is his fell, and foul, reputation.
As a great and powerful Bruiser, Bragg is welcomed into any tribe he joins... until he turns on his fellow Ogres, of course!
Hand-reared as hatchlings, tamed Wyverns instantly respond to the bone-deep impulse of the Waaagh! when called by their Orc masters.
Black Orcs are the biggest, strongest, meanest, most brutal and least pleasant of all Greenskins. Act accordingly.
Goblins rise to power not through raw strength, but through their sheer cunning and deviousness, which enables them to manipulate certain others quite easily.
After a prolonged period in the desert wilds, this Great Shaman has developed a new trick or two for tracking and stalking his prey.
Many a Great Shaman has perished learning the sought-after art of spider whispering, leaving only those who had as much antivenom as they did luck.
The Goblin Shamans of the Little Waaagh! can cast a shroud across their army, setting up the most perfect ambushes.
Little Waaagh! spells are surprisingly sneaky – subtle, even, which is much more surprising for those on the wrong end of one!
It’s possible this Great Shaman may have been a Wolf Rider himself at one point, such is his affinity for the ways of lupine-mounted warfare.
Every living Greenskin from the World Edge's Mountains to the Badlands and beyond knows Gorbad for his "invasions done propa".
Once dere busy, smash 'em from da sides!
Youse stan' dere an' smash anyfin dat comes close! Gottit?
Gatha 'round, ladz! I gottit all worked out...
Get behind me, I'll chop 'em apart!
Don't charge in yet, shoot 'em with da arrers an' rocks till dere mostly dead, yeah?
Find da biggest and tuffest boyz ya can and tell 'em dere's some smashin' to be done!
Grimgor's desire for battle knows no bounds. He can *never* be slaked... On to da next one!
Any Black Orc worth their pride considers it the highest honour to be part of Grimgor's Immortulz.
When Grom calls a Waaagh!, Goblins of all stripes flock under his banner, bringing loads of crazy contraptions to impress 'da Great 'Un'.
Only the bravest Night Goblins dare climb on the backs of the wildest Squigs. Finding such a gobbo is easier said than done!
None seez 'til I doez the deedz, an' den dem bonez will rot on da stonez!
There is no one whom the Night Goblin Big Boss has faced and hasn’t ran away from – and no one whose back he has seen and hasn’t stabbed, and killed.
Experienced Night Goblin Herders can spot a Squig with the temperament to be controlled... and know to stay well away from those that cant'!
Betcha ya expected da high blow! Ha!
We 'aven't fed dese ones for a few days – lets release 'em on da enemy gitz, so dey can eat dere fill!
It takes a lot of dirty tricks and a fair share of luck, but those who last this long are truly dangerous ladz to have around.
The bigger the Waaagh!, the bigger the spells, and the greater the Shaman's power.
The ability to create discomfort among friend or foe through their gaze can be quite disarming, allowing for the Orc Shamans to act freely and manipulate events as they unfold.
While an Orc Shaman will primarily dance around chanting their magic, never forget that they are Greenskins, and Orcs at that. Get too close and they'll still rip your arms off!
The Savage Orcs are a highly superstitious bunch, and will always dance to their insane Shamans' twisted, insidious beat, whenever they hear it.
The Orc Shamans often chant incoherently while dancing around camp, much to the discomfort of da boyz.
While locating enough paint for such a job isn't easy, no one can deny the results are suitably impressive!
Red paint would make the boars run faster; this war paint will give them some protection.
Any Shaman worth his weight in paint makes sure that his own markings are every bit as potent as those of his warriors.
The magical warpaint that protects da boyz is always greatly appreciated on an Orcish battle line.
A master schemer and the epitome of shrewdness, Skarsnik has little trouble convincing his fellow Goblins to 'commit' themselves to less favourable jobs in his Waaagh!
A warlike army's journey to a pile of peacefully rotting mulch goes through the forests where the Deff Creepers lie in wait.
Fizzy deff iz da baddest deff!
Toof-spider likez tuff meat, likez tender meat, likez your meat!
Some Forest Goblins have been known to take it willingly to induce dreams of the Spider-god. Their enemies take it most unwillingly, to induce lethargy and death.
Snagla’s mob has a penchant for the feathers worn by Empire troops, which they soak in their slaughtered owners’ blood and place upon their weapons and shields.
Born under the Drakwald's canopy and nursed in the Black Pit's depths, Snagla can ask even a tree-leaf's shadow to accommodate his murderous skulking, and it will oblige.
Drink da red venom an' sleep now, soft-'ead.
It is easy to dismiss the Forest Goblins' Spider-god as a hallucination. Arachnaroks rampaging across a battlefield are not quite as easily dismissed, however.
As sharp as Fangspike, it scrambles the brains of all who hear it. If poison were a sound, it would be *this* sound.
It is when Snagla's eyes go dull that his murderous instincts become sharpest.
Run, Spider, run! Eight legz enna dream!
The Warboss' trophy rack displays all the skulls, tusks and claws of the large beasts they've felled.
It's only right and proper that the biggest, baddest, most violent Orc in a warband carries the largest, most offensive looking axe.
The bigger and badder the Warboss, the more boyz that will flock to his banner.
The Warboss' trophy rack houses the skulls of all the men, Dwarfs and Elfs, and myriad other beings whom he has ignominiously slaughtered.
The twin gods of the Greenskins, Gork and Mork are perpetually fighting… something, and quite often, each other, mirroring the Greenskins indiscriminate nature!
Da Great Green Prophet inspires religious zeal in all Greenskins, his most ardent followers being those of his own savage brethren.
Having led a mighty Waaagh! into the beating heart of Imperial territory, Gorbad Ironclaw can whip any Greenskins rabble into an effective fighting force.
From the moment a Northman grips steel, he imagines himself a new Arbaal. He needn't imagine, for here Arbaal stands, unvanquished and as inexorable as a glacier.
Skarr Bloodwrath has died numerous times, always to be brought back to life through the spilled blood of his foes to reap such a tally of skulls that none can keep count.
If he wants to find you, he will. When he challenges you, you cannot refuse. When he comes for you, you cannot stop him.
Golgfag got his name after an… 'incident' over gold with a human Paymaster who briefly served the company…
Would you die ignobly as He watches? Would you have your flesh spun into a Spawn? If so, I shall kill you myself. If not, follow me.
What devotions a Daemon Prince garners by dint of his miasmic aura, Arbaal achieves by sheer might of will.
The millennia seem to have not taught Arbaal patience in battle. And in truth, he has as much need for it as does a hurricane against a hovel.
Arbaal is the ever-living proof that a human being is no lesser a conduit for the Ruinous power of Khorne.
Nothing hones the blade of a Khornite better than the wailing of initial onslaught and the blood spattering its aftermath.
Sever the head and the rest will crumble.
Blood shall flow for all eternity.
Slaughter begets slaughter, and those who lead the charge inspire ferocity in their lessers.
In choosing his next battle, the Bloodspeaker does not consider his army's fatigue or the losses it has incurred, but only whether the next foe is within reach.
To fail and not die in the service of the Bloodspeaker is an ignominy. Such warriors are no longer warriors. They are skull-carriers.
A warrior whose gait is Daemonically driven has a peculiar effect on the battlefield. The air twists. The earth bubbles. His foes die before they realise what happens.
When a Bloodspeaker opens his mouth, Daemons take note. In the mortal realm, such attentions are no mere curiosity. They grasp and seize.
A Khornite carrying a severed head is a horror to be expected. But it is said the Bloodspeaker's trophy exhibits a different, and quite personal, horror to those who behold it.
You begin your path as equals in worth. In time, some will prove… more equal than others.
The murmur of one's own blood is the first language one learns. Most forget it. The Bloodspeaker does not. Such private conversations yield a public spectacle to behold.
The larger the prey, the larger the guts to tear and bones to grind.
Most worthless of all are those who take false surety from cowardly sorceries.
And in his shadow, the most favoured slaughter eightfold, their bodies girded in blood.
Blows to shatter mountains, unbreakable form to weather the storm.
Death approaches on crimson wings, and cowardice only delays the inevitable.
It takes a true warrior's will to halt the killing long enough for subtlety.
The slaughter starts long before the Daemons pour in.
Kill, bleed, die. The blood flows!
Among the hordes, even the lowliest are brutal warriors.
What better training than an ambitious underling?
Champions earn their exaltations in the heart of battle.
Writ upon the battlefield in the blood of their enemies, the so-called Lesser Daemons of Khorne reap their gore-soaked toll.
Fire that melts steel and incinerates flesh, yet allows the blood to flow all the same.
When the quiet comes, the reaping only escalates.
When the quiet comes, the reaping only escalates.
A sliver of the Blood God's favour, but a great one nonetheless.
War is the natural state of all things, peace is the lie that mortals whisper to themselves.
Each victory reinvigorates Khorne's champions to seek more bloodshed.
A small measure of Khorne's power rests in Skulltaker's bare hands. The power in his sword is another matter altogether.
One scar is enough. For that, Sigmar's whelps will pay in full. As will all others. I do not believe in half-measures.
No death is ever enough. Even if Skulltaker claims the greatest champion in all the realms, another will be born, and die in turn.
Other Khornites fear my presence, so I cannot imagine what it does to a mere mortal.
Skulltaker's challenge is only aimed the  worthiest of the worthy. He pays no heed to its reverberations, but the aftermath is there for all to see.
Unique among Khorne's Chosen Champions is he, for none of his Bloodletter kin has ever challenged him, and not because of his title.
The finest warriors, both mortal and immortal, have fallen to the Slayer Sword in mere seconds. Anyone who is less than that is a mere skull waiting to be collected.
The more this general follows Da Plan, the better they get at using Gorbad's Tactics.
Being a Bruiser is simple: be bigger and stronger than everyone else, and smack seven shades of dung out of other Ogres to remind any would-be challenger who is boss.
Bruisers always gravitate towards the thickest bloodshed in battle, looking for any opportunity for wholesale slaughter.
Stopping chariots with their bellies, breaking entire formations by themselves, or squishing the life out of enemy Champions – these are the deeds of a true Bruiser!
Acting as a Tyrant's enforcers, Bruisers pummel any Ogre who dare step out of line.
The Tyrant's right hand and loyal war advisor, this Bruiser will serve and protect his boss to the end.
There's no better Maneater to judge whether candidates for recruitment into the Maneaters are Maneater-material than Golgfag Maneater… as you might hope and expect!
Golgfag has seen it all, done it all and killed it all many times over… and won't be stopping anytime soon.
An army that isn't picky about its meals never goes hungry.
We find a fight, beat 'em all up, then we loot 'em, then we eat what's left of 'em and then we do it all over again somewhere else. It's the perfect job.
As the most successful Ogre Maneater of them all, Golgfag's reputation has made other famous mercenaries keen to prove their mettle by his side.
Sometimes, the most useful things in life are just left lying around the place for someone to stumble across…
A fair day's 'work' for a fair day's pay, right?
If they get to me, then none of ya's gettin' paid! So keep me safe n' hidden!
I know, why don't we make it interestin'? An extra five pieces per 'ead, shall we say?
It’s dangerous business to promise the same loot to multiple parties, but it certainly gets the job done!
The Paymaster always gets first choice of the loot. 'Tis the privilege of rank… and proximity to the war chest.
If you want to get paid, and indeed stay alive, it's sensible to do whatever you're told to do – and be quick about it.
When the bell sounds, it's snack time for the assembled host. Then, the carnage can begin again, on a full stomach, with all of the associated drawbacks!

Covered head to foot in (someone else's) bodily effluvia, stinking to the heavens, yet very much a conduit for the Great Maw's insatiable hunger and thirst, and the horrific violence that inevitably follows.
The best way to stay out of the pot is to do as the Tyrant says and be happy about it.
The more blood, guts and general goo, the more the Gut Magic is rooted in the real world, where things really matter.
Hack, grind, cook and eat. Those Butchers are alright. Don't get near their pots though...
Scyla's durability has barely been tested. No battles against him last long enough. Yet, what lies dormant, gathers strength.
The Chaos Wastes breed relentlessness in destruction. Many can achieve that against their opponents. Few can inflict it on whole peoples, and the lands they inhabit.
Khorne shudders with fury to hear magic incantations. But the power of a mantra in His name cannot be overstated, especially if it is the only words one knows.
Did… did it just *speak*? Gods have mercy on us!
Scyla cares not for the words of the ones he is supposed to be fighting alongside. But some undertake to ingratiate themselves with him nonetheless.
The unnatural Winds carry his words still. His voice now carries those selfsame winds that push entire armies ever forward.
Every time Skarr claws his way back from the dead, a little more burns away, until only the fury remains.
Skulls so innumerable that, were they dust, they would be a wasteland. All Skarr's doing.
Both 'blunt' and 'instrument' are, in fact, misnomers. Yet, a scalpel it is not; that much is true.
Skaramor Chieftains come and go. Their leader is but one… er, man.
In the lulls between slaughters, the flaming tornado of Skarr's blades is still seen from afar. He would snuff out the very Winds, if he could.
Blades that burn through magical protections, scintillating barriers that deflect blows. Azrik leads a warband of terrifying magical might.
Strike us down all you wish, then break yourselves upon our bodies..
How can a man cross snow without leaving a single track?
Stain the snow red! Fill the valleys with their dead! Hoist their skulls upon every mountain!
I have many names, many titles… Harbinger, Dark Master, Lord of Shadows.
This world will end, the End Times are coming. I have crowned the last Everchosen.
Daemon-Whisperer, Puppet Master… but you, you may call me… a God.
On the field of battle, this Ice Courtier is truly in her element, for it is here that her magical training can be put to best use.

Always use the local guides. They know more about this land than you ever will.
Skilled at keeping the wheels on the caravan, even in the middle of nowhere.
