The Dragon Emperor guides every sword and spear of the northern provinces, inspiring a strength of arms to match an unflinching strength of will.
From lowly peasant to expert marksman, every arrow of the east soars with a Draconic power and grace.
Ancient Cathay stands historically unconquered. Booming cannons and rockets of exploding fire help ensure it will remain so.
Who can withstand a charge with the sweeping force of a hundred hooves in unison?
Even the most inexperienced peasant rallies under the cold-eyed gaze of Cathay's most stoic guardians.
When fire hangs in the sky above the battlefield, death is sure to rain down upon it.
Cathayan armies have been tested time and again, their skills proven in a tumultuous arena of bloodshed and near-constant war.
When the raging of battle begins, swift hands and swifter feet are the keys to surviving at range.
Swift, steady and moving as one, the hardy warriors of Cathay race headlong into battle.
A blanket of glowing lights amidst the clouds is sure to stir the heart of every Cathayan warrior beneath them.
The blood-soaked battlefields of the northern provinces are the proving grounds upon which the mightiest warriors of Cathay have honed their craft.
Every wound that is not fatal is but a lesson to learn from.
All warriors of honour and pride are eager to fight under the Dragon-Emperor's banners.
Sky Lanterns are used by the Dragon’s armies to observe enemies from on high.
A general's horse can be their most trusted and daring companion. Just don't name him 'Daisy'.
This leader imparts his knowledge to the battalion, and they are willing to learn.
Land the size of Grand Cathay requires a pragmatic custodian.
What weapons can hope to pierce the rigid scales of such a monstrous and majestic beast?
A rampage of talons and teeth will carve through the heart of any foe.
When an enemy thinks they are safe at range, it is best to prove them wrong.
When defending the Great Bastion, one must follow up a missile volley immediately with another.
The Storm Dragon's every movement is imbued with a predatory swiftness and grace.
There is no rest in the midst of battle, only the seething storm of relentless aggression.
There must be order in all things, and from that order, harmony.
The Storm Dragon's spine must remain steadfast against every looming threat that lies beyond it.
Miao Ying is trusted above all to guard the north, serving as Cathay's most steadfast champion.
Miao Ying stands vigilant against the armies of Ruin, for Order is the only true answer to Chaos.
Where the Storm Dragon goes, the winds of Yin seem to blow strongest of all.
Crafted from the unusual minerals of the Warpstone Desert, Zhao Ming's armour protects him from all but the fiercest blows.
The strength and ferocity of the Iron Dragon and his forces have never been in doubt. His sanity, however…
Though madness seems to tug at Zhao Ming's mind, his mysterious crafts are nonetheless effective, relentlessly harrying Cathay's foes.
Ogre mercenaries are a common sight in Shang-Yang, where their battle prowess benefits the armies of Cathay.
Cabals of Metal and Fire Wizards are welcome in the Western Provinces, where their strange alchemy bolsters the fortress of Shang-Yang.
The armies of the Iron Dragon harness his mighty strength, tearing through the armour of their enemies.
Weapons crafted in the Western Provinces are forged from the strongest metals of the Warpstone Desert.
The Winds of Yang flow robustly in the Iron Dragon's presence.
There is no greater embodiment of Khorne's all-encompassing wrath than spilling the blood of a weak and pitiful enemy.
A weapon forged in a fire of searing hatred strikes harder than any average blade.
Emerging from the Forge of Souls trapped in a prison of metal and gears, the heavy machinery of the Clinkerspawn possesses an undeniably brutal strength.
When the Harvesters of Doom take to the field, a violent ringing of metal echoes with every mechanical swing and thrust of their blades.
The dead and the dying have no use for material goods, and the living do not deserve to keep what they could not protect.
Khorne thrives in the wake of wanton destruction; let the towns and cities of his foes burn to the ground around them.
The Blood God rewards the agents of His glory, for what strengthens the Lord of Murder so too bolsters his forces.
Deliver rampant Chaos unto the unwary, and all manner of powers shall be awarded in Khorne's name.
Warriors pledged to Khorne never tire of war, but are honed by battle fury into sharp instruments of violent rage.
The putrid stench that emanates from the warriors of Nurgle is somehow not the most deadly thing about them.
The pox-ridden plague sweeps down upon its victims, like all the best virulent diseases.
This macabre grotesquerie of rancid creatures in service to the Plague Lord are notoriously hard to kill.
Every attack from the most putrescent of the Fly Lord's offspring leaves behind a miasma of rot, infection and disease.
Though fighting with a graceful elegance, every strike from the warriors of Slaanesh lands with devastating impact.
It is easy to be distracted by the beauty of Slaanesh's mounts, even as they close in to deliver your agonising death.
Even the most monstrous creatures in the Dark Prince's armies possess a horrific sort of beauty, lulling their victims into the most fatal kind of complacency.
The most ardent servants of pleasure take great joy in the artistry of war, vehemently cutting down the enemies of excess.
Their loyalty to the Raven God grants the warriors of Tzeentch a staunch hardiness in battle, for what is change if not the ability to overcome?
Racing into battle at great speed, the Tzeentchian cavalry put every bit of their momentum into each and every strike.
Creatures of all kinds serve the Wind Lord, whose magic imbues them with a strength and speed to transform living foes into dead ones.
Tchar's greatest warriors lead the field of battle, weaving the twisting threads of violent Change around all that surround them.
When you strike a warrior of Khorne, strike hard and with more strength than you dare, for what doesn't kill them only makes them stronger, and angrier.
Astride terrifying mounts and riding rattling chariots of bone, the forces of Khorne are a whirlwind of pure destruction on the charge.
The bestial minions of the Blood God charge the enemy, ripping and tearing at their flesh until no breath remains.
The loyal champions of Khorne delight in the brutality of war, delivering the skulls of the vanquished to the foot of the Skull Throne.
Pure, irrepressible rage is but an act of worship to the Blood God's glory.
The true experience of divinity can be found in the ecstasy of indulgence.
Follow the changing winds, and the blessings of the Raven God can be earned amidst the tempest.
As the corruption of Chaos seeps into the land like a sickness, the glory and strength of those forces pledged eternally to Ruin can only grow and grow.
This willing servant of the Ruinous Powers has a resilience that is beyond any mortal measure.
What better protection is there than a stench so stomach-churningly revolting that it repels every creature in its wake?
It is hard for any weapon to penetrate such an overflowing mass of bloated flesh.
Thick plates of filth-ridden, Daemonic metal deflect all but the most grievous of blows.
With the mechanical whirr of heavy gears, the Soul Grinders of Nurgle launch foul projectiles over impossible distances.
The perils of passing through hostile terrain matter little when the Lord of Decay guides your path.
Disease and decay ravage the corpses littering every battlefield, reinforcing the blighted warriors of Nurgle.
Those most devoted to Grandfather Nurgle's noxious cause sustain themselves wholly on the infectious virulence of their Lord.
As Nurgle's withering decay spreads, plaguing the mortal realms, the power of His faithful followers only continues to grow.
Infect the weak, spread a plague or two, and let glorious Chaos sweep the land – these are the accomplishments that garner the Plague God's favour.
The art of combat is much like an intricate dance – fluid, graceful, and always building up to a killer finale.
Weapons should be as finely honed as the body, and both should be capable of inflicting the most wicked harm in Slaanesh's name.
Though being trapped in a prison of hellish Warpmetal is torturous for a soul inclined to freedom, the raw power it grants somewhat eases its burden.
Capturing the beauty of battle is impossible from inside a mechanical tomb, yet the pleasure of the kill is no less enticing.
The expression of surprise on an ambushed foe's face is always a particularly delectable treat.
The Dark Prince rejoices to see such Chaos sown amongst his foes.
Few need much persuasion to serve the Prince of Pleasure; the draw of pursuing one's every debased fantasy often proves too tempting to resist.
The pleasures of battle are often all that is needed to sate a warrior's appetite.
The powers promised by Slaanesh are alluring indeed, and worth any price to acquire.
As the Dark Prince's malignant influence spreads, his followers are most delightfully rewarded with abilities beyond even their wildest dreams.
A wall of perilous flame lets nothing pass through it without burning the intruder to cinders.
A cocoon of wing and feather provides protection to the Lords of Change, sheltering them from harm.
Amidst the storm of Change stand those chosen by T'char to lead the realms into the heart of its churning maelstrom.
Encased in Daemonic Warpmetal, the Soul Grinders of Tzeentch feel no pain but the agonising thirst to finally be free.
Allies of the Raven God lurk in every corner of the map, ready to change the tide of war from any direction.
Every being desires change in some form or another, and a point of common interest is where all successful negotiations begin.
The warriors of Change are driven ever onward by motivations constantly in flux.
The Winds of Magic dance around the Bringer of Change, swirling through the ranks of his Sorcerers, who draw power from its potent energies.
The tides of Change rise and fall, imbuing dark power on those who have proved themselves worthy.
The Great Sorcerer grants many gifts to His most faithful Heralds of Change.
Chaos grips the local populace with an iron fist, discouraging all disorder lest it tighten and choke.
The corruption of Chaos infects all it touches, stretching its dark tendrils out across the land.
Many servants of Chaos are connected by a Ruinous web that joins their forces in common cause.
The provinces shall bloat with wonderous corruption, expanding amidst the glory of success.
Raging and roaring in the cause of Chaos Undivided, the forces of Khorne bray for battle with even greater fury.
The unwholesome, decrepit warriors of Nurgle stand bolstered among the united forces of Chaos.
Merged under a single Ruinous banner, the servants of Slaanesh find new pleasures within this unholy alliance.
The unified forces of Chaos thrill the Lord of Change, who delights in seeing once-fierce enemies transformed into a weapon of untold annihilation.

Once of the Dragon Emperor's artillery legions. Though now an independent trader, those ties are hard to break.

Hails from Nan-Gau with strong ties to the barracks of the Nine Rings, its guilds and troops.

Brought up in Shang-Yang, with an intimate knowledge of its denizens and alchemist guilds.

In a battle of wills, one must not falter.

No being can kill what it cannot catch.

If knowledge is power, then this one is powerful indeed.

Some beings are simply made for the cloak-and-dagger games of subterfuge.

The trick is to think two steps ahead… and then think one step ahead of that.

Hardy and resilient, this being stands firm in the face of all challenges.

The Dark Gods empower me, so vengeance will be mine.

If you don't kill them outright, to spill their blood and scar them for life is almost as good.
My hammer's a cold piece of blood-lethal steel. I grin while you writhe with the pain that I deal!
If there's trouble to be had – and by that I mean the worst kind of slaughter – this one will always be at the centre of things, instigating the conflict.
Some men are natural leaders, born to foster and marshal their tribes through devastating wars and the harshest of winters.
For those used to life in the oblasts, keeping the elements out is only the beginning of the measures they must take to ensure the survival of their people.
This valorous warrior has been at the forefront of the struggle against Ruin before, and they certainly shall be again, steeled and girded by that dreadful experience.
By right of his storied experience, this one is trusted to make sound judgements in the best interests of the Motherland.
The ancient Khan-Queen Miska practised Ice Magic to the very highest grade; this one studies her methods in the hope of attaining similar greatness.
Using the wealth of the Orthodoxy, the Ataman can make great improvements, drawing the populace - as long as they only partake in sanctioned Orthodoxy worship.
With a head for building and trade, such a skilled individual is vital to the efficiency of local production.
The people of the north fare well under the guidance of able administrators.
In Kislev, worth is not just conveyed by birth, but by the spirit as well.
One must never underestimate the importance of effective administration. The livelihood of many in Kislev depend upon it.
Even as the corruption of Chaos creeps ever closer, the oblasts and stanitsas of Kislev stand resilient.
Under sound leadership, Kislev grows more prosperous by the day, even in the screaming, rotting, laughing, lying face of the oncoming hordes of Chaos.
A nation of weaklings and cravens would have long since succumbed to the Daemonic horde. Kislev is no such nation.
The endless defence against Chaos has done little to dim the spirit of Kislev's citizens, whose hearts remain resolute against the darkest of corruptions.

Kislev is the people, and the people are Kislev!
If you love the Bear you will happily die rather than be taken!
If you spend almost any time too close to this vile infector you'll regret it, assuming you live to tell the tale that is.
Unusually subtle for one so foul, this one is skilled in spreading Nurgle's insanitary ways and words across the land.
This one finds the enemy can barely stand to come near them, let alone attack.
When this one's countless lesions and warts finish weeping and harden up, a natural, protective carapace is left behind in their place.
If a population are confined to their toilets or beds at home they're not able to spread dissent and sedition as readily, if at all.

Today the Orcs, tomorrow the world. Let them all tremble!...

The more meat you eat, the stronger and fatter you become, and therefore the harder you are to move from your chosen position.
There may or may not be a height difference between this one and his Ogreish colleagues, but in stature on the battlefield the divergence is most stark.
Remember, lads, when Great Maw came 'e ate the night, shook the ground and burnt it with fire. That is 'oo we serve, not sum uvver power.
I yearn to taste their delicious agony.

This one's eerily seductive beauty has proved to be most useful both in the bedroom and on the battlefield.
Flawlessness is not an unattainable goal for those who serve the Perfect Prince; for the chosen few, it can be a reality.

Blessed with the transformative boons of Tzeeneth, this one can travel further by his feathered wings, whether they be figurative or literal.
Beguilement and confusion are exuded wherever this servant of Change walks, foxing even the most adept combatants and magic-users.
This one has become the conduit through which the Great Conspirator weaves His sorcerous webs, affecting glorious Change through magical means.

This one seeks to sow the seeds of confusion, dissent and dishonesty, for such are the insidious ways of the Changer.

Into the heart of the enemy race the feral hounds of havoc and destruction.
The diabolic engines of war rumble with the endless wrath of the Blood God himself.
Battles can be lost, but can the war ever really be won? The advance of Ruin can never truly be halted once and for all.
With the servants of Chaos comes the corruption – as the landscape twists, this one speeds the transformation.
This Khornate Lord's well of eternal rage never runs dry, nor does the ceaseless influx of warriors eager to serve under his command.
Every skull taken in the Blood God's honour proves this one's loyalty to the Skull Throne.
This brutal Lord of Khorne decimates the lands of man and monster alike – the avatar or wrath incarnate!

The beasts that roam the forests of Kislev are somehow even more lethal than the land they inhabit.
Kislevite craftsmen toil night and day, tinkering with contraptions to help repel the forces of Chaos.
The workshops of the north are always busy, their engineers working tirelessly in the pursuit of battle excellence.
Those with the know-how to move mountains build palaces in their stead.
Rouse yourselves, layabouts! The wolves gather, and I won't have my soldiers play at being sheep!
Pre-emptively shipping excess harvest to outlying villages significantly cuts spoilage.
Roving patrols enable early warning and mobilisation in the event of enemy incursion.
The best routes aren't found on maps, but in the knowledge of those who have walked them a thousand times.
Rotating wounded soldiery with fresh garrison troops allows armies to quickly recover.
Beyond mere garrisons, dedicating officers to maintaining forces for deployment allows for rapid mobilisation.
When the dust settles, hard-earned lessons must be preserved for the future.
A rota of sentries is a small but important layer of security for any frontier.
Though many consider the politicking of the Court a waste of time, those who play the game reap the rewards
When trouble comes knocking, it helps to have powerful allies.
This one often meets with Ice Witches of the Court to confer on the future of his demesne.
The truly devout walk with the favour of the Kislev pantheon as icons of the community that others readily serve.
As battle is met and axes are raised, so too are the voices of the fervent.
There is no other way but to adhere strictly to the teachings of the Great Orthodoxy.
From ice-packed dirt shall come fertile fields.
Better to be the hunter than to be the hunted.
A personal touch ensures that negotiations go their way as often as possible.
Boris' every heartbeat echoes with the courage and tenacity of Ursun.
Hold tight to duty and rid the mind of all fear, for fear is a threat to the Motherland.
Every enemy has the right to bear arms. And the right to be horrifically mauled by bear-teeth.
I don't know what effect these men will have upon the enemy, but by Ursun, they frighten me.
All that was lost to Chaos shall be reclaimed, in Ursun's name for the good of all Kislev.
Following centuries of devastating conflict against Ruin, the cities of Kislev shall rise again, stronger than ever before.
You've got to lose yourself before you find yourself, back in exile…
Ursus the Red, the greatest of Kislev's rulers, commands respect from those wishing to treat with the frozen kingdom for common cause.
The Great Bear shall be reborn, and the Motherland with him.
Boris' return heralds a period of unprecedented growth among the Kislevites, proving his intrinsic connection to the Motherland and its people.
Greatest of all the bear mounts, the 'Bear-brother' who awaits his legendary rider, Boris Bokha.
A general's horse can be their most trusted and daring companion. Just don't name him 'Daisy'.
Champions know there is glory in striking down great foes, but battles are more often won by the many and not the few.
Many foes have broken upon the frozen ramparts of Kislev, and for every anvil there must be a hammer.
Harden your heart with glacial resolve.
At the core of Kislevite doctrine, the storm of steel.
What is the bite of an arrow to the freezing sting of a northern hailstorm?
Battle is the crucible in which Heroes are forged.
Loyal, fierce, powerful and surprisingly fast – a War Bear is a symbol of Kislev itself.
A general's horse can be their most trusted and daring companion. Just don't name him 'Daisy'.
Death is like a winter chill; No door can keep it from us; And summer yet may bloom againThough ice be all upon us.
Loyal, fierce, powerful and surprisingly fast – a War Bear is a symbol of Kislev itself.
A general's horse can be their most trusted and daring companion. Just don't name him 'Daisy'.

A general's horse can be their most trusted and daring companion. Just don't name him 'Daisy'.
There are any number of mysterious wonders secreted away in the shadows, for those discerning enough to find them.
Kislev's coffers will be overflowing! The things we could do with all that gold!
There is much to be learned from one's neighbours, especially if they fail to shroud their discoveries from prying eyes.
Show no mercy for the enemies of Kislev, for they will show no mercy to you!
Often the most dangerous assault comes from the enemy you least expect.
Loyal, fierce, powerful and surprisingly fast – a War Bear is a symbol of Kislev itself.
A general's horse can be their most trusted and daring companion. Just don't name him 'Daisy'.

The Ice Queen rules from a majestic frozen palace, where whole chambers are carved from the most potent ice magic.
Small walls and mountains of ice are known to spring from the ground around Katarin, a frozen bulwark against the deadliest of threats.
The oncoming tide of Chaos never ceases, yet Kislev will never fail to rise up and fight against it.
A hastened stream of ice and snow flows with the Tzarina, moving as one with the frigid wind.
Though stemming from superstition bred from whispers alone, there are many that believe Katarin to be Miska, the glorious first Khan-Queen, reborn.
Cold and deadly – Katarin is the personification of winter itself, and armoured in its biting chill.
There's nowhere to run once the Snow Leopards begin their hunt. Only close your eyes and hope you are not their prey.
Loyal, fierce, powerful and surprisingly fast – a War Bear is a symbol of Kislev itself.
A general's horse can be their most trusted and daring companion. Just don't name him 'Daisy'.
If Kislev and its people are to endure then they must fight to the death, lest the foe take all for which they have strived.
What the peasants really want, whether they know so or not, is a strong man; a man with will of iron so strong that death itself runs in his wake.
Faith in oneself and one's cause are at least as important as martial skill, if not more so.
Those among the faithful who show talent and promise soon find themselves raised up within Great Orthodoxy to inspire and lead others.
There's nothing quite like a pious Kislevite man scorned, especially one whose rage is stoked by the finest kvas.
The power to rouse the rabble to terrific violence in a heartbeat is not to be underestimated.
The Great Orthodoxy shall see Kislev rise again, mighty and without peer, with Ruin defeated and destroyed utterly.
Loyal, fierce, powerful and surprisingly fast – a War Bear is a symbol of Kislev itself.
A general's horse can be their most trusted and daring companion. Just don't name him 'Daisy'.
Frail as they may seem, there is no doubt the Gods guide the Patriarch's arm, and lend him their strength in defence of the Motherland.
Kostaltyn’s flat metal discs, inscribed with Ursun’s runes and icons, inspire even greater deeds when awarded to the worthy.
The longer you believe, the more intense that faith becomes. When your belief is total, there is nothing that you cannot achieve.
Surviving wounds that would have killed lesser men, it is clear that this one bears the favour of the Kislevite gods.
The Patriarch speaks with the voice of the gods, spreading the spirit of Kislev far and wide.
This one's stentorian roar ensures that his blood-and-thunder missives always reach their intended recipients.
An animal so vicious, no others fought and won. So on the fields of battle, we are the chosen ones!
Rest is for the weak; one must harry the enemy in relentless pursuit and leave them no time to regroup.
Loyal, fierce, powerful and surprisingly fast – a War Bear is a symbol of Kislev itself.
A general's horse can be their most trusted and daring companion. Just don't name him 'Daisy'.
Long has peace in the Old World been bought with the blood of Kislev. When Ruination descends, none are more ready to meet it than the hardy guardians of the north.

Hidden skill to grant Kroq'Gar's Saurus characters extra scaling
Cold, merciless, without pity, obeying only logic. Hardened against magic's ill-effects.
Unchained by the malaise that afflicts the Slann, the Lord of the Solar-City spurs the unnerving vigil of the Temple Guard into vehement zealotry.
Saurus mark the passage of time through the ever-increasing hoariness of their scales and the ossification of their battle-worn plates.
Featureless slabs of obsinite used for the Saurus’ weapons are reinforced with cruelly misshapen jade and, most importantly, gemstones symbolising the favour of Sotek.
Every skirmish thickens the corded muscle of the surviving Saurus, increasing their resilience commensurately with their instinctual understanding of battle manoeuvres.
The Great Plan seems beyond reproach when faced with eight feet of scar-ridden reptilian muscle festooned with the shrunken heads of sacrificed foes.
Solitary reptilians marked for greatness appear where the Old Ones first imprinted their will, emerging from the glow of sacred spawning pools beneath cavernous temple-cities.
Fighting in the shadow of their more colossal kin, cold-blooded warriors hone their spatial perception in combat at a pace younger races cannot comprehend.
A singular shrill call is all a formation of vibrant-crested warriors needs to release a whirring blowgun swarm, burying deep into all exposed flesh.
Heightened aggression is often a characteristic of appointed Skink Chiefs. To excel, one needs to interpret the subtlety in orders from the greater coldbloods.
An instrument of foresight in the execution of the Great Plan, an unpredicted and solitary spawning of a twin-tailed Oracle can produce an especially learned individual.
Staring into reflective waters, a Slann can comprehend world-spanning visions of which a Skink prognosticator is allowed but a glimpse.
Through the unwitting replication of certain patterns of the Geomantic Web, a ritualistic daubing of warpaint can apply unseen protection to the Oracle so marked.
The ceaseless consternation stemming from the presence of the Chaos Moon also spurs the arcane ingenuity of the cold-blooded astromancers, often aimed at its destruction.
Resonance with the great gongs of a three-horned temple requires a pilgrimage to the claustrophobic depths of the jungle – and more importantly, demands sacrifice.
When the mystic chains that tether them to the clouds are properly aligned, the ornate floating temples are an instrument of effervescent, self-realising contemplation.
A mass of primordial horrors, withering the limb and sapping the vigour of a warmblood, is perceived as a favourable omen to the devout Lizardmen.
Serving as conduit for the eyes of the esteemed Slann is a privilege with unexpected benefits, attuning lesser kin to a sliver of their masters’ arcane aptitude.
It is said that through feverish reverence, even scales mottled with age will gain the serpentine, amethyst quality of the fabled Coatl – a potent ward against vile wizardry.
The Wizard draws wholesome energies from the soil, imbuing companions with the natural resilience of the earth.
This spell temporarily transforms allies' mortal flesh into unbreakable rock, increasing tenfold their resistance to attack.
By speaking Druthandor's name the Wizard is able to heal allies' injuries much faster than by natural means.
By speaking Druthandor's name the Wizard is able to heal allies' injuries much faster than by natural means.
Sets some baseline behaviours to smooth out the governor pipeline.
Anything fired at this vile Nurglish servant's immense girth must penetrate many folds of sweaty fat before they even have the slightest chance of piercing his flesh.
The dread steeds of Chaos are more than mere horses, but creatures tainted by Daemon blood, said to be gifts from the Dark Gods themselves.
Dwarfs? What are they good for? And always so bad tempered. The terrible beauty of disease is not for their sullen eyes. Why can't they just die, in agony, as other mortals?
The Fly Lord and his devotees despise Tzeentch, for his obsession with schemes and trickery are the polar opposite of Nurgle's delight in slow, musty stagnation.
The palanquins of Nurgle are ornate thrones decorated in mouldering finery and decaying cushions.
A colossal Daemon-insect, whose appearance is so repugnant it leaves festering scars upon the mind.
The palanquins of Nurgle are ornate thrones decorated in mouldering finery and decaying cushions.
A colossal Daemon-insect, whose appearance is so repugnant it leaves festering scars upon the mind.
This living (well, sort of) ammunition tumbles and capers towards its target before exploding in a shower of foul pus.
My bedfellows are pestilence, famine and war… but mainly pestilence.
Virulent disease, preferably in tandem with the foulest stench imaginable, is the best defence the Plaguefather's beloved Nurglings could have.
While other Great Unclean Ones merely spread disease, the Foetid Brewmaster is ever breeding new, more virulent poxes to delight his master and destroy the foe.
Ku'gath not only deals in disease, but also attracts the very best candidates to Nurgle's banner to fight and kill and be favoured in their turn.
Such is the sheer size of Ku'gath's gut that he can produce more and better Nurglings than other Great Unclean Ones in the Fly Lord's service.
The Plagueweaver's slime trail renders opponents impotent and vulnerable to his disgusting, fatal intentions.
Imagine a rubbery, pus-filled bag lurching towards you. Now imagine it is travelling at twice its usual speed...
Sensible enemies think at least twice before attacking such a diseased specimen, for even if they win, chances are they have caught something really nasty along the way.
Grandfather loves the smallest of his many children at least as much as his myriad other grim creations, if not more so.
The flying things are beloved of Nurgle, for they are, oft-times, the method of infection for his most potent, hideous infirmities.
None more foul. None more black. Yuk.
A poisonous malady so hideous, even death is no escape.
The corrosive ooze emanating from the most ulcerous sores is one of the most effective weapons in the Urfather's foul armoury.
The air most creatures breathe provides just another avenue of attack for Nurgle and his many and varied contagions.
Blade and point and spell can be turned aside very easily by the Fly Lord's most-favoured servants.
With the servants of Chaos comes the corruption – as the landscape twists, this one speeds the transformation.
Those corrupted by Nurgle's rot flock to his putrid banner in the hope that they will be reborn anew in Grandfather's image.
You will serve me, wretch, or you will die, there is no other option.
Just as all life is born, so it must wither and die. Before that happens comes disease, in all its disgusting, filth-ridden glory.
The palanquins of Nurgle are ornate thrones decorated in mouldering finery and decaying cushions.
A colossal Daemon-insect, whose appearance is so repugnant it leaves festering scars upon the mind.

A colossal Daemon-insect, whose appearance is so repugnant it leaves festering scars upon the mind.
Stumpy and short-witted as they are, these Gnoblars have an eye on the sky at all times.
Even ferocious brutes like the Ironguts and Maneaters fight harder in the presence of a worthy leader.
Though their intelligence is as pitiful as their physique, one would be a fool not to fear the Gnoblars when massed in numbers.
The Ogres' true firepower is as destructive and indelicate as the Ogres themselves.
What the monstrous creatures of the mountains lack in guile, they more than make up for in their stubborn reluctance to die.
If there's one thing more horrifying than being rushed by a hulking, bloodthirsty beast, it's being rushed by that same creature riding on the back of another equally hulking, bloodthirsty beast.
When an Ogre charges, the ground itself begins to quake. As it should.
When pelting a helpless enemy with heavy projectiles is so much fun, why bother stopping?
When fearsome, brute strength is combined with terrifying speed, the petty weaklings among the enemy can only wet themselves in fear.
Driven by ravenous hunger, the Maneaters feast on the flesh of the fallen.
To the most brutal, vicious killer go the richest spoils.
Regular consumption of rotten meat and toxins are the staples of a healthy Ogre diet.
One can never go hungry on a long march for as long as there are captives for the meat-pot.
The grumblings of unrest tend to quiet when under threat of being crushed and eaten.
Even Ogres are capable of forward planning, especially when it comes to precious loot.
Through a bloody haze of visions, the Butcher sees a great many terrible wonders.
Every army needs a warrior with a fire burning in their belly. Literally.
A sword of searing heat cuts through flesh as if tearing through a damp scroll.
Those who have gorged upon the magma of the Fire Mouth harness the very essence of its burning rage.
Scorch the earth and set whole cities aflame – the Fire Mouth will claim all in the infernal blaze.
Even walls cannot protect you from a fire that cannot be quenched.
The best offence is a good defence. And the best form of defence is to belch an impenetrable wall of flame.
Da Wanderer, they call 'im da Wanderer – 'e roams around, around, around, around, around.
As menial slaves to the Butcher's bidding, these Gnoblars must find him meat for the pot, or wind up in it themselves.
Puny magicks are nothing in the face of the Great Maw's endless hunger.
A small handful of Gnoblars surround this Ogre Lord, their swords always ready to cut and carve.
It never hurts to keep your lucky Gnoblar with you, just in case.
Running a large camp is one thing. Running an effective camp is another entirely.
Wealth, greed and glory are enough to make any basic war camp swell in size.
The largest wealth draws the largest warriors, and few are so wealthy as Greasus Goldtooth.
Just as Greasus' form has grown to such absurd proportions, so does his unfathomable wealth.
There are no war camps in all the land to rival those of Greasus Goldtooth.
Carried by his weary Gnoblar slaves, Greasus is armed and armoured right to the teeth, and is the very picture of domination.
Step 1: Grease up your Gnoblars! Step 2: Go faster!
If flesh and conquest are your deepest desire, the Tyrant of all Tyrants is happy to provide.
You have to watch 'em, as there's no telling what malicious schemes those wickedly cunning Gnoblars might enact.
Once the other tribes laughed when Greasus demanded they pay him tribute. The fools would be laughing on the other side of their faces, if indeed they still had faces…
You're a big git, but you're in bad shape. For me, it's a full-time job – now behave yourself.
More arrers means more chances for this big lumbering git to score a direct hit on his dinner.
For such corpulent creatures, Ogre Hunters are capable of truly surprising speed.
Every spear culminates in a devastating point – all the better for skewering helpless meatbags by the dozen.
Well-trained Sabretusks can roam freely, prowling the land for their next unsuspecting meal.
Like a living boulder, Stonehorns are breathing fossils that are belligerent and mighty when roused to war.
To tame the ferocious Sabretusk requires time, skill and a whole lot of raw meat.
No beast is too big to be brought to its knees. More meat on its bones is simply more meat for the feast!
This one has guts – quite literally. A surfeit of stomach in fact, you might say, but also the confidence to back up his bulk.
How does one combat a pack of angry, charging Sabretusks? is a question usually asked moments before tragedy.
As ravening, carnivorous predators, Sabretusks are driven into frenzy by the first scent of blood.
One might think a pack of vicious predators would be difficult to miss, yet these Sabretusks are adept at silently hunting their prey.
The best way to eliminate a target is to violently crush their skull before they even notice you're there.
Run! RUN! Oh gods, they're coming right at us!
It's hard to shelter from missile fire when projectiles are being launched with enough force to impale a particularly sturdy tree.
When the beast master says jump, his pets only wait to hear how high.
Never one to run with the crowd, this one likes to sneak about in front by themselves and surprise the foe – which isn't necessarily an easy thing to do when you're an Ogre!
A Bellower’s voice is as deep as it loud, carrying across the battlefield and encouraging unbridled carnage.
Ogres flock to this Butcher's camp, eager for the chance to witness the Great Maw's malevolent power.
Wealth is much easier to come by when the omens are guiding your path.
Flesh, limbs, blood and bone – it all goes into the meat-pot!
The mysterious powers of the Great Maw can heal even the deepest of wounds.
This ravening Ogre Lord is but a mere symbol of his god, whose cancerous power reigns over the Mountains of Mourn.
Once the slaughter begins, every foe is but meat yet to be carved.
Where this one goes, his meat-pot goes too, as a bounteous reserve for his spells.
If the enormous size of this Ogre doesn't incite terror, his bloody, malevolent smile surely will.
This Ogre's greed shall never be sated, for his stomach is as endless as his hunger.
A truly sturdy armour is needed to hold such an overflowing gut in place.
No enemy is immovable when in the path of a furious Ogre's charge.
Once a vision begins takes form, Skrag is relentless in pursuing its path.
Skrag's power allows him to appease the Maw with a smaller tribute from time to time.
Not even the darkest corruption can escape the Maw's devouring influence.
The Maw's eternal hunger can never be sated, by mortal means or otherwise.
Skrag knows the dark caverns under the mountains like the back of his bloated, unwashed hand.
When the Slaughterer goes on the battlefield, only the spray of blood and scattered limbs are left in his wake.
Snapping limbs and smashing skulls – it's all in a day's work for an Ogre Tyrant.
The Great Maw protects and the Great Maw devours. Hiding in shadows, the meatbags cower!
This Tyrant is the size of several large creatures rolled into one. In fact, he ate those several large creatures just yesterday.
Mountains of gold and an overflowing meat-pot are bound to draw in the strongest of warriors.
Rule number one of being a leader is to be far more terrifying than the next braggard who thinks they ought to take your place.
It is not enough to impose military defeat upon the foe, they must be brought to their knees through punitive taxation… unless they'd rather get in the meat-pot instead?
If the shock of your limbs being cleaved clean off doesn't kill you, the poison on the blade surely will.
A full meat-pot and stolen enemy plans really does wonders for camp morale.
Stop yer wriggling, meatbag! Into the pot you go!
Only when bathed in blood and gore can the Gastromancy of the Great Maw be channelled.
Wherever the Butcher goes, a trail of dismembered limbs is sure to be left behind him.
The Slaughtermaster speaks as the Great Maw wills, and all of the faithful listen well.
Fetch me more bones! This meal could use a little crunch!
The reeking odour seeping from this one's every pore would offend any creature with a nose, and several without.
Kill a creature with poison and it seeps into their skin – gives that yummy flesh an extra kick!
Not even the darkest corruption can escape the Maw's devouring influence.
The best part of such rampant slaughter is the gory feast that follows.
More flesh for the feasting means more punishing magic for Skrag's foolish enemies!
Swift flashes of an agile form and razor-sharp blades are all this Daemon Lord's victims see of him, but by then it's already far, far too late.
This one’s writhing form can slowly caress and tease, but also move like lightning when required, knocking a projectile from the air or batting it back at the foe.
Exalted Chariots are a blur of chromatic scythes and slicing blades pulled by Slaanesh's steeds.
Straining steeds urge the chariot to full speed, where swirling shapes sear the air with unholy hues.
Steeds have long, sinuous bodies that writhe ceaselessly as they dash towards the foe.
Exalted Chariots are a blur of chromatic scythes and slicing blades pulled by Slaanesh's steeds.
Straining steeds urge the chariot to full speed, where swirling shapes sear the air with unholy hues.
Steeds have long, sinuous bodies that writhe ceaselessly as they dash towards the foe.
The enemy are overtaken by a somniferous perfume that induces sleep in spite of the din raging all about them.
The dread steeds of Chaos are more than mere horses, but creatures tainted by Daemon blood, said to be gifts from the Dark Gods themselves.
This obsession with murder is just cheap, mindless bloodlust of the basest kind. To the servants of Slaanesh, there's so much more to life… and to death too, of course.

Steeds have long, sinuous bodies that writhe ceaselessly as they dash towards the foe.
When you can speak their language, convincing weak-willed mortals to give in to their base desires and gift their souls to Slaanesh is, unsurprisingly, quite an easy thing to do.
Even the Children of Slaanesh can be inspired to ever greater depths of depravity.
The warriors of Slaanesh waste no time in hunting down their victims, for the heady delight of the kill is as addictive as it is exhilarating.
Atop their powerful beasts of Slaanesh, the Seekers dart across the field of battle, cutting through their foes with devastating precision.
There's little to do against the advance of a bladed chariot but to be ground beneath its heavy, bloodstained wheels.
The minions of the Dark Prince carry out frenzied slaughter in his name. Their victims' abject despair is but a delicious feast for their master.
Pleasure and pain sit on either side of a fine-edged blade, and the greatest of Slaanesh's servants delve eagerly into both extremes.
The endless pursuit of hedonistic delights further corrupts even the most depraved of creatures.
The true veterans of battle exude an aura of rapturous fulfilment, dulling the senses of their lessers.
The kiss of a lover, or the kiss of a blade – the decadence's Devotees will have you begging for both!
There is no end to the power a being holds once it can tug at your wildest fantasies and twist your darkest fears.
With the servants of Chaos comes the corruption – as the landscape twists, this one speeds the transformation.
The Perfect Prince can never have too many Devotees. It matters not one jot to Slaanesh whether they come to him willingly or are coerced into His worship.
The Prince of Pleasure whispers in the ears of all, pulling at the threads of their every deviant desire.
Having given itself willingly to the service of Slaanesh, this force requires neither the carrot nor the stick to fight for Him though either one would no doubt be pleasurable!
For such a lithe, sinuous form as N'Kari, simply brimming with unchecked power – where seduction fails, gleeful murder poses no challenge.
Even those influenced by violent Chaotic rage may succumb to the allure of wild, impure, licentious abandon.
Foolish hypocrites! The arrogant pride of these Elves brings them far closer to Slaanesh than their egos would have them believe.
For N'Kari, and other intrepid disciples of Slaanesh, His temptations truly know no bounds...
Scorched by unforgiving Nehekhara, warriors’ bones endure by the will of the Mortuary Cult. Through monotonous precision, their droning incantations infuse resilience.
At the cusp of the age of man, Asaph – the Goddess of Vengeance and Magic – took on the symbolic form of an asp, as did her acolytes.
Centuries of bloody warfare have seen countless enemies pulped against Nehekhara's unwavering, bejewelled skull-shields – a will that has only ossified in Undeath.
Beneath a death mask's facade of glowering luxury slumbers a desiccated visage, grimly honoured on the frontlines in eternal servitude to its embittered monarch.
In ceremonies that touch upon the Realm of the Dead, incantations must be meticulously intoned, for they encroach upon Usirian’s rightful due.
Blistering in their intensity, invocations of the Sun God sear blinding visions of the Great Land's restored splendour – just as Ptra ordained.
Bleak as a panorama of necropoli. Painful as a Khepra beetle down your throat. Such is the sorcery of these disciples.
Shadows are the liminal tracts between presence and absence – the clandestine habitat of Qu'aph in the hooded form of a Khemrian cobra.
Among the shifting dunes, dawn is heralded by the scrape of sand against the panoply of war, and the murmur of long-buried warriors.
With just a wave of the hand, projectiles fired at this servant of Tchar are turned from sharp and pointy to soft and entirely harmless.
The dread steeds of Chaos are more than mere horses, but creatures tainted by Daemon blood, said to be gifts from the Dark Gods themselves.

Perhaps it is the Fly Lord's apparent nonchalance that enrages Tzeentch so? Whatever the reason, the Great Game's greatest player, and his greatest servant, have an adversary on which to focus their ire.
Hurtling across the realms like incandescent meteors, Burning Chariots bring Tzeentch's emissaries to the foe.
As part of the binding ritual, Screamer bodies are flattened and transmuted into unlikely aspects.
Burn so bright, burn so nice, it's a crying shame you can't die twice!
Now do it again... but better.
The meanest streaks give rise to the greatest potential.
Hurtling across the realms like incandescent meteors, Burning Chariots bring Tzeentch's emissaries to the foe.
As part of the binding ritual, Screamer bodies are flattened and transmuted into unlikely aspects.
To deter retribution, tomfoolery is best indulged in as a group.

Surprise is half the battle. The other half is pure, unadulterated terror in the face of certain madness.
Having effected Change upon one's enemies, what next for the Mocking Watcher? More of the same, naturally, for to do so over and over again brings the sweetest of raptures.
Who pays the piper? Why, Fateweaver's opponents, of course, with their minds and souls as coins of currency.
When you know all there is to know, as does Kairos, nothing is beyond the reach of your grasp.
Those who cannot think clearly and lucidly are unable to resist the insidious creep of Ruin.
Battle unfolds rather predictably for one who sees that which is yet to happen.
Every possible future blazes with the light of sorcery and change.
To see the future is to know which tools can most efficiently enforce the fickle whims of Tzeentch.
To know the future is to understand the true futility in mortal flailings against fate.
I could tell you of your defeat this day, but your future has already arrived. So let us meet it together, you and I.
Infinite pasts lead to this point, where the foe is destroyed utterly in service of futures pleasing Tzeentch numbering nine times nine.
Though blind to the present, Kairos can look into the future and begin weaving spells far in advance, layering multitudinous slivers of power for just the right moment.
Fateweaver may harness the Winds of Magic to his best advantage, for he already knows all the possible outcomes of his actions.
The unstoppable magician can draw the Winds to him and bind them for protection more easily than other practitioners of the craft.
Of all the gifts bestowed by the Dark Powers upon their followers, the boons of Tzeentch are surely the most desirable.
Kairos' scribes faithfully record every baleful whisper that passes his lips, that they be made real, in the form of the Daemonic Horrors that do his bidding.
Though all who serve the Changer are gifted with additional protection from attack, some can restore it to maximum effectiveness faster than others.
The Oracle of Tzeentch is a magic-user of such power that he operates outside of the forces that constrain lesser spellcasters and hamper their designs.
Enchantments such as these may be strengthened further by those with the requisite magical skill.
Though they may appear ridiculous, the whirling, screeching footsoldiers of the Great Conspirator are the iron in his feathered martial glove.
Although it can be said that they have failed His tests, the broken minds and fluctuating, mutated bodies of Tzeeneth's lesser minions still have their uses.
Unburdened by mass, Tzeentch's flaming servants surge toward the foe – the heralds of their utter doom, no less.
The thundering of their Chaos Steeds and chariots announces the arrival of Kaldour's dread Knights, and death is never far behind them.
For the Winged Watchers and Doomstriders of this world, their very lack of identifiable corporeal form shall be their armour against attack.
Even the bravest, most rational souls waver in the hideous, laughing face of their worst nightmares.
Of the many weapons available to Tchar, derangement must surely be the greatest and most satsifying to wield.
The flickering beings of flame are in many ways the purest servants of the Changer, for their gaseous forms are ever in a state of flux.
The best form of defence is attack, and the best form of attack is the one which reaches into the foe's mind and turns its contents against them.
With the servants of Chaos comes the corruption - as the landscape twists, this one speeds the transformation.
The many faces of the Wind-lord are described here, along with all the terrible mysteries of destiny. Between these lines lurks insanity, ever waiting to trap the unwary.
The many faces of the Wind-lord are described here, along with all the terrible mysteries of destiny. Between these lines lurks insanity, ever waiting to trap the unwary.
Tzeentch knows that at their cores all beings desire Change, and as such there are no shortage of recruits willing to march under his many-coloured banner.
The promise of Change, though it may amount to nothing more than the cruellest of tricks, ensures the forces of Tzeeneth are fed and nourished.
As they are a most adept and dedicated magic-user, where this one treads, the Winds always blow high and hard.
All the world is fuel for the pyre of Change.
The mere presence of such a mighty Lord of Change girds lesser Daemons tenfold.
The ever-shifting sky is but another part of Tzeentch's great domain.
The Winds roil and buck at the whims of this eldritch creature, it alone can direct the Chaos!
Without the concern of limitations, spells can be turned into raw obliterative power.
It was clear after the battle that the fiend the men had spoken of was but an image of a distant and more terrible foe…
No mortal host shall hold them back.
The dead may rest uneasily in the Chaos Wastes, yet Harry has no shortage of foes across the world upon which to vent his anger.
One bad road can kill a man – unless you're me.
We show no remorse for the deeds of death and destruction!
A lifeless object, alive!\\nAwaiting Reprisal!\\nDeath will be their acquittance!
They're infected with death, they know they have to die.
Never break it, it will never bend!\\nThe Anvil was forged in fire!
This world has come undone\\nArmageddon has arrived...\\n...in the shape of a killing machine!
Chasing down those who have drawn the Blood God's ire, Karanak drives his fellow Flesh Hounds to snarling madness in glory of the hunt.
The unrelenting vitality of Khorne’s chosen Hound affords him even greater strength for the hunt and the final moment of violence.
An eternity of grinding down bones of slaughtered prey and discarded from the Skull Throne has tempered each of Karanak’s jaws.
The most nightmarish of Karanak's heads tracks his quarry through its own thoughts, pursuing them through dreamscapes and delusions.
Karanak’s three snouts sniff the air for traces of his prey, each savouring a portion of the scent and following it to the ends of the earth.
To become Khorne’s chosen hunter takes ruthlessness, implacability, and the zeal to serve the Blood God’s vengeful whims unquestionably.
The need for fresh red meat is not driven by hunger for sustenance, but the unholy exhilaration of consuming an enemy’s flesh.
The most unyielding of Karanak's heads can follow a scent through time; back to the moment of the creation of everything, or forward to the end of the universe.
At the fore of his dreaded pack the Daemonic apex predator stalks his prey, his slavering kin following cautiously in his stead.
Across a thousand kingdoms and realms beyond, the bestial chorus of Karanak’s hunt has long since become the harbinger of dire fates.
The most ravenous of Karanak's heads follows his victims through physical reality, tracking them over plains, forests, mountains and environments too bizarre to describe.
None offer greater insult to the Blood God's colossal pride than the Dark Prince's hedonistic acolytes, making them the prized trophies of Khorne's chosen hunter.
The already-fierce Chaos Steeds are often covered in heavy armour, making them even deadlier.
The dread steeds of Chaos are more than mere horses, but creatures tainted by Daemon blood, said to be gifts from the Dark Gods themselves.
Manticores are highly prized by Sorcerers, for they are creatures bathed in magic and as cruel as their riders.
The weird, evil moon hangs low in the sky, drawing reverence from its abominable worshippers.
This spell calls to the creeping things of the undergrowth, sending a swarm of spiders, centipedes and slug-beetles onto the foe.
Chaos smiles upon them, granting unnatural and heretical defence against mortal machinations.
Those strong enough to tame the powerful, unruly Razorgors can harness them to chariots.
Those strong enough to tame the powerful, unruly Razorgors can harness them to chariots.
Those strong enough to tame the powerful, unruly Razorgors can harness them for chariots.

Hurling themselves into battle, a whirlwind of appendages and weapons strike, unexpected and deadly.
He knows. Nobody knows how, but he does. He has always just known.

The warherd waits, allowing the enemy to come to them. Nature is their defence, as man will soon find out.
The warherd waits, allowing the enemy to come to them. Nature is their defence, as man will soon find out.
The warherd charges out, slathering jaws and bellowing in fury. Against the charge, none can stand.
The warherd charges out, slathering jaws and bellowing in fury. Against the charge, none can stand.
A strong leader can bend the will of the warherd to his own, and reap the benefits of it.
A strong leader can bend the will of the warherd to his own, and reap the benefits of it.
The warherd, though vast and hard to control, can be relied on to fight, fight, fight!
The warherd, though vast and hard to control, can be relied on to fight, fight, fight!
The unquenchable thirst for blood is indiscriminate; prey and kin alike are fair game.
Fur-clad, matted with offal and detritus, their weathered hides are a foul carapace.
The Beastman's tusks are drenched in gore - blood and sinew from every foul battle.
The howl of battle is the signal, a promise that butchery will be done.
Those strong enough to tame the powerful, unruly Razorgors can harness them for chariots.
At the head of the warherd, he whips his followers into a frothing furore, then unleashes them upon the enemy.
In fitful dreams, he sees the end. The world collapsing in on itself, leaving nothing but ashes and aberration.
The stench of raw, rotten meat causes others to balk, but the warherd revels in the flesh and brawn.
Khazrak knows nature, he knows the world. He sees, knows and is prepared. Mankind cannot best Khazrak.
Unknowingly, the Beastmen serve their dark and Ruinous Gods, who in turn bless their every action.
We feel it. We all feel it. The pull to war. The tug of battle. The NEED to kill.
With the servants of Chaos comes the corruption - as the landscape twists, this one speeds the transformation.
This willing servant of the Ruinous Powers has a resilience that is beyond any mortal measure.
They bray beneath the weird, green moon, and do their perverse, grim butchery in the name of the heretical Gods.
Lordship to the mighty! Power to the strong! Obedience is earned through bloody victory!
For those who face the warherd, a fate worse than death awaits their salivating jaws and unremitting bloodlust.
Brought into this world by the cataclysm of Chaos, Beastmen are the very image of a dread future.
Even when not feasting, the Beastmen taste blood on their lips, smell it on their fur, and want for more.
The ground shakes. The earth moves. The spirit trembles. The Beastman comes.
When the warherd gathers, there is much feasting, debauchery, and revelling in mania and depravity.
The Beastman's fury stretches back before most can remember - they pursue their hatred with single-minded zeal.
The stench of magic is palpable. No mage can stand in the midst of battle against the baying warherds.
The world of man will fall at the Beastlord's hand, with every glittering city reduced to rubble and despair.
The great green orb hangs ominously in the sky above, its followers driven to acts of madness and depravity.
With a base howl, the beast radiates strength and power, a warning to his enemies that death is coming.
The desire to wreak havoc is innate, brought about not by choice but by sheer force of being.
He who locks horns with this master of the warherd does so at his own peril.
No beast can truly be controlled, but these desperate contrivances bring the smallest semblance of order.
Carved into this battered and dishevelled stone is the mark of violent rage and sanguine desire.
A snorting, hulking mass of blood-matted, mud-encrusted, sanguine-soaked fur - the Beastman is a terror to all.
The blood is the prize. The blood is the prize! THE BLOOD IS THE PRIZE!
The Ruinous Powers grant many gifts to their obedient servants; mutant disfigurements of flesh and might.
A summons to war in which all are drawn into the cacophonous charge; glory or sanguine death is the prize.
It is never enough. The food, the drink, the slaughter. It is never, ever enough.
The Beastman delights in constant fighting; in vicious, ceaseless brutality. It gives him purpose.
The clamouring Beastmen know only the fire of bestial rage in their hearts. It is best to stoke that fire into an inferno.
What do the Ruinous Ones care for the trifling tricks of mortal conjurers? They will not suffer their thralls to be afflicted by paltry delusions.
The Beastmen do not take prisoners; why would they be given weapons of war if they were meant to show mercy? No! Kill!

An Imperial pegasus is a noble, winged steed, intelligent and loyal.
While Wizards can rarely benefit from armour, a warhorse does offer some degree of protection and manoeuvrability.
With a roar, it pointed, and a pack of nightmare dog-beasts turned their feral attention towards me.
Into the mud with them, break their skulls and eat their hearts!
“Morghur returns. Morghur spread Gods’ corruption. Many die but all fall to Ruin. ALL!”
With a mighty bellow, the caster invokes Corvus the Crow Lord, summoning his servants to peck at the foe's eyes.
Calling upon the beast spirits of the wild, the caster sheathes vulnerable flesh in unyielding fur and hide.
Sounding a gnarled horn, the caster summons a glowing amber spear and hurls it at the foe with uncanny accuracy.
Nebulous nature spirits assail the foe, clawing at them with hands not nearly as insubstantial as they appear.
Kadon, a master of forms, was able to shift his shape into anything he chose. This mastery is used to summon a Manticore, as if Kadon himself fights for you.
The spellcaster attunes the magic of the wild, channelling its ancient and arcane power.
The spellcaster unleashes the beast within, using its fury to transform allies into bestial forms.

This spell unleashes a howling roar of such intensity that it mashes brains and bursts eyeballs.

A red-hot spear of wrath is driven into enemy mounts' wild hearts, causing them to turn upon their riders.

Into the mud with them, break their skulls and eat their hearts!

Surrender and serve me in life, or die and slave for me in death.

From atop Ghorst's nightmarish chariot pulse waves of puissant energy, enervating the undead and excoriating the souls of the living.
Helman Ghorst knows what he should not, but knowing is not enough – he must utilise this denied knowledge.
What Helman Ghorst has lost, he will reclaim – no power of this world or beyond will stop him.
Devilish chariots imbued with dark and eldritch power, driving the Undead to greater, more macabre acts.

“Do you understand? You are more than you were – more than just flesh and bone; you are everything that defines us."
The first arrow of battle must fly truest.
Even the simplest of spells can bring forth the full bloom of renewal, reinvigorating and healing the broken and bleeding.

By speaking Druthandor's name the Wizard is able to heal allies' injuries much faster than by natural means.

Nightmares are often clad in heavy barding or wear caparisons of thick chainmail.
Hellsteeds are vicious. Vampires that dabble in the binding of beasts delight in breaking these wild creatures to their will.
The most impressive Nightmares are those reared on fresh blood. Such noble monstrosities are worthy mounts.
To me, my winged steed of bone and flesh; let us fly and remake the world together!
It is to the Plain of Bones that a Vampire Lord travels to claim a Zombie Dragon as their mount.
No hide nor armour can stand against the piercing fury of a Dryad or Tree Kin's savage limbs.
Hewn from the same forest that surrounds them, Tree Kin withstand attacks like the forest withstands the fury of the seasons.
The Lord's troops are charged to fight for Athel Loren, for their very souls are tethered to its fate.
Let the enemy feel the fury of nature, embodied in these warriors as they crash through their lines.
Armour as hard as the ancient bark of the forest, it repels blows that would rend others asunder.
All of Athel Loren shouts with a fury as old as the ages, and the enemy knows its power.
The warrior strikes with the strength of a swinging tree limb; few can stand against such strength.
The Lord embodies the forest; as a result of this, their warriors feel a greater call to defend it.
The Lord charges their troops to fight for Athel Loren, for their very souls are tethered to its fate.
What is a ranger without an arrow? Who can be the best without dozens?
The Asrai are fleet of foot, with centuries of darting from branch to branch, and never a missed step.
A ranger should give no reprieve to the foe. Arrows must fall like a deluge, as deadly as lightning.
Let each bolt be imbued with the strength of Kurnous, and bring death to all his enemies.

This Lord can spot an enemy at a distance that defies belief, and demands their troops do the same.
Waystalkers’ keen eyes can spot an enemy at a distance that defies belief, and so they demand the same of their troops.
The Mother protects her forest-dwelling children, wrapping them in an ethereal blanket, hardening them against their foes.
When at war under the canopy it is like the trees themselves join the fray, striking from all directions.
The forest has a great rage, which is manifest in its warriors' violent deeds in Kurnous' name.
From all corners of the forest, they come to defend their homes.
The denizens of the forest will travel many miles to see those who would threaten Athel Loren put to rout.
The Worldroots provide succour for their children, purging the forests of any corrupting infestation.
The forest provides for its warriors, rehabilitating and regenerating wounds suffered in its defence.
Like the forest itself, the warriors of Athel Loren ebb and flow and regenerate with the passing of time.
Eons spent darting between branches and canopies unseen has given these warriors the advantage over their foes.
Athel Loren provides for its deserving children, with wondrous boons gifted in recognition of their many endeavours.
The magics of the woods obscure and connive, able to turn enemy blades away from their targets.
The forest-dwellers draw from the strength of Kurnous to fight ever harder, and be ever stronger.
The dead do not want for material possessions, yet the living may yet find value in them…
Always willing to fight on, a widened quiver allows arrows to rain, almost without end.
Using the forest itself as a shield, this Lord is protected by their devotion to Athel Loren.
What the enemy cannot see, it cannot hit. What the enemy cannot see, it cannot survive.
There is no greater thrill than to be in the midst of battle, slaughtering in the forest's name.
Nook and fire. Nook again, and fire. Nook a third time, and fire. All in a heartbeat.
Taking their cue from the forest itself, the Lord endures and overcomes all.
When to strike, when to block, when to dodge. These are all skills the warriors of Athel Loren must perfect.
The forest teaches a warrior not only when to fire but where, which makes a bigger difference.
When the arrow flies farther, it may kill sooner, which is vital in the Hunt.
By all means summon the bloodthirsty Goddess of the Hunt to assist you, but always make sure you thank her afterwards…
Elven hunters emulate Kurnous, the God of the Hunt. Their speed and swiftness is therefore without peer.
Hailing from deep within the forests of the Old World, this dragon breathes deadly, poisonous fumes instead of fire.

Nothing escapes this Dwarf's gaze; no movement, no trap, nothing.
Night Goblins are sneaky and pervasive - they creep and crawl from every hole to join in the killin'.
Grimnir fought with every breath, and so too must those who follow in his name.
Wise is the Dwarflord who scouts ahead, with his vanguard ready to surprise the foe.
He knows that the faster he can throw boulders at the enemy, the faster he can win.
A Ranger does not need much - he is sustained and guided by the needs of his people.
What a Dwarf doesn't know about defending a Hold isn't worth knowing.
The undertaking of Belegar swells the hearts of most Dwarfs, inspiring some to take up axe and hammer.
When one spends his life killing one thing, he becomes exceptionally good at it.
Belegar carries his enormous Oath Stone everywhere. In dire times, he stands tauntingly atop it to fight to the end.
King Belegar's cause is one all the Dawi can get behind - the Karaz Ankor *will* rise again.
Powerful oaths have been spoken by Belegar; he will not give up, for the rage within is strong.
Covered in the Runelord’s ancient script, the anvil has given form to the most powerful runic weapons ever forged.
All Dwarfs despise the Greenskins, for the urki and grobi are the prime agents in the Times of Woe.
Invoking the Rune of Hearth & Home stirs a Dwarf's pride in his Hold, Clan and Ancestors.
A Runesmith may 'strike the runes' - a metaphor for refusing to let them cool, which reduces their potency.
Night Goblins are vicious little beasts with addled-brains and despicable little plans.
Orcs may be stronger, but Goblins are smarter, nastier, and better-er.
No need for 'smarts' or thinkin' like a Goblin. Just smash 'em harder; that's the Orc-y way!
A Squig is an unconventional mount, but survivors say it has a certain charm.
If there's something that a Savage Orc can't smash to bits, then it probably can't be smashed.
Every cave and ditch is a hiding place for these Goblins - you cannot hit what you cannot see.
They march because they're told to, and of course because they'll get a 'right proper thrashin'' if they don't.
These Savage Orcs, and the Warboars that bear them, give no quarter on the battlefield.
If Night Goblins know one thing, it's that victory is victory, no matter; in fact, the sneakier the better.
A gift to Wurrzag from the Iron Pig tribe, Spleenrippa is his dependable, and terrifying, War Boar mount.
Those on the wrong side of Wurrzag find themselves blasted apart by his magic or, worse, turned into Squigs!

“The Peaks belong to me. I dare yoo to try and take ‘em from me, stunty.”

An assured air instils great confidence in your followers.

The finest horses in the Old World, bred for their endurance and fiery temperament, barded for further protection.
Alberic's personal Hippogryph, broken years prior when the duke was a young Knight Errant, is an especially fearsome specimen of an infamously savage species.

By which the person of the Fay Enchantress may remain unmolested in the face of sustained attack.

This proud and noble Unicorn elevates the Enchantress above her host, so all may see and be strengthened by her blessed presence.
That which is sacrosanct I shall preserve\\n That which is sublime I will protect\\nThat which threatens I will destroy\\nFor my holy wrath will know no bounds...
That which is sacrosanct I shall preserve\\n That which is sublime I will protect\\nThat which threatens I will destroy\\nFor my holy wrath will know no bounds...
A figure of awe and inspiration, hers is the will of the goddess.

When the clarion call is sounded\\n I will ride out and fight in the name of Liege and Lady\\nWhilst I draw breath the lands bequeathed\\n unto me will remain untainted by evil\\n Honour is all, Chivalry is all...
Those whom the Lady has blessed fight with an unquenchable, almost super-human zeal, for they know that she sees them.
No one is more accomplished in the Lore of Life than the Fay Enchantress.
The king's symbol stands for valour, tactical skills, and the righteous. It is assurance of trust.
This ancient symbol of Bretonnian supremacy, blessed by the Lady’s kiss, shines with a golden light as if brand new.
King Louen’s shield has protected him from the first days of his Knighthood; strengthened by enchantment, it will continue to do so.
The finest horses in the Old World, bred for their endurance and fiery temperament, barded for further protection.
Stronger and faster than the mightiest warhorse, these intelligent beasts are exceptionally loyal to their noble masters.
